text.0_Annullment of Vows, 0_Paragraph: The Talmud (Maseches Nedarim) says, “Whoever does not want his vows, made during the year, to remain in force, should declare: “Any vows that I make during the coming year are hereby nullified.” The Tur writes that it has become a widespread custom to recite the “Kol Nidrei” before Yom Kippur for the purpose of nullifying all such vows. He further writes that since זְרִיזִין מַקְדִימִין לְמִצְוֹת, the diligent come early to perform their religious duties. It is commendable to invalidate one’s vows before Rosh Hashana with the declaration contained in the “הַתָּרַת נְדָרִים,” the Annulment of Vows.
text.0_Annullment of Vows, 1_Paragraph: The Talmud and Halachic sources explain that the annulment of vows or oaths, applies only to those which one imposed on himself, such as, “I will eat” or “I will not eat”; “I will sleep” or “I will not sleep,” and other such vows or oaths. But for that which one vows or swears to his fellow, or if someone places him under oath, regardless of that person’s nationality or religion, no annulment, invalidation or absolvement is ever possible.
text.0_Annullment of Vows, 2_Paragraph: One should therefore stand before a minimum of three adult males and declare:
text.0_Annullment of Vows, 6_Paragraph: konom-vow,1According to the Talmud, a vow is when one says that such is forbidden to me as is—a קָרְבָּן, a sacrifice. In place of the word korban, the word konom was frequently used. There is a dispute in Maseches Nedarim as to the origin of the word. or consecration,

text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 0_Paragraph: When Rosh Hashana occurs on Thursday and Friday, an eiruv tavshilin must be prepared on the preceding Wednesday. The head of the family should take bread or matzoh and an item of cooked food such as meat or fish, put them on a plate and say the following berachah:
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 2_Paragraph: our God, King of the Universe
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 3_Paragraph: Who sanctified us with His commandments
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 7_Paragraph: it will be permissible for us
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 8_Paragraph: to bake, cook, keep dishes warm,1“Keeping dishes warm” means that we are permitted to place cooked foods on a covered stove in order to preserve their heat. An example of this is the traditional Cholent.
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 9_Paragraph: to kindle a light (from an existing flame),
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 10_Paragraph: and to prepare and do all our necessities
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 11_Paragraph: on the Festival for the needs of Shabbos,
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 12_Paragraph: for us and for all Jews2The Rav of the community usually includes the community in his eiruv. This can be done however by anyone. It is done by handing over the cooked food to another person through whom he grants a share of the food (of the eiruv) to the entire community. This person raises the eiruv a tefach, (handsbreadth) and returns it to the one making the eiruv.
text.1_Eiruv Tavshilin, 14_Paragraph: The food of the eiruv should be eaten at one of the Shabbos meals.

text.3_Mincha for Erev Rosh Hashana, 0_Ashrei: Fortunate are those who dwell
in Your house;
may they continue to praise You, Selah.
Fortunate is the people whose lot is thus;
fortunate is the people
for whom Adonoy is their God.
A praise by Dovid!
I will exalt You, my God, the King,
and bless Your Name forever and ever.
Every day I will bless You
and extol Your Name forever and ever.
Adonoy is great and highly extolled,
and His greatness is unfathomable.
One generation to another
will praise Your works,
and Your mighty acts they will declare.
The splendor of Your glorious majesty,
and the words of Your wonders I will speak.
Of Your awesome might, they will speak,
and Your greatness I will recount.
Mention of Your bountifulness
they will express,
and in Your righteousness joyfully exult.
Adonoy is gracious and merciful,
slow to anger and great in kindliness.
Adonoy is good to all,
His mercy encompasses all His works.
All Your works will thank You, Adonoy,
and Your pious ones will bless You.
Of the honor of Your kingship,
they will speak,
and Your might they will declare.
To reveal to men His mighty acts,
and the glorious splendor of His Kingship.
Your kingship is the kingship for all times,
and Your dominion is in every generation.
Adonoy supports all the fallen,
and straightens all the bent.
The eyes of all look expectantly to You,
and You give them
their food at its proper time.
You open Your hand
and satisfy the desire of every living being.
Adonoy is just in all His ways
and benevolent in all His deeds.
Adonoy is near to all who call upon Him,
to all who call upon Him in truth.
The will of those who fear Him, He fulfills;
He hears their cry and delivers them.
Adonoy watches over all those who love Him,
and will destroy all the wicked.
Praise of Adonoy, my mouth will declare
and all flesh will bless
His Holy Name forever and ever.
And we will bless God
from now forever.
Praise God.
The Chazzan recites the following half-Kaddish
Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
in the world which He created
according to His will;
and may He rule His Kingdom
in your lifetime and in your days,
and in the lifetime
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future—
and say Amein.
May His great Name be blessed
forever and for all eternity.
Blessed and praised,
glorified, and exalted and uplifted,
honored and elevated and extolled
be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
above
all the blessings and hymns,
praises and consolations
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
text.3_Mincha for Erev Rosh Hashana, 1_Amidah: and my mouth will declare Your praise.
our God, and God of our fathers,
God of Avraham, God of Yitzchak,
the Great, the Powerful, the Awesome,
Who remembers the piety of the Patriarchs,
for the sake of His Name, with love.
King, Helper, and Deliverer and Shield.
You are mighty forever, my Master;
You are the Resurrector of the dead
the Powerful One to deliver us.
Sustainer of the living with kindliness,
Resurrector of the dead with great mercy,
to those who sleep in the dust.
Who is like You, Master of mighty deeds,
and who can be compared to You?
King Who causes death and restores life,
and causes deliverance to sprout forth.
to restore the dead to life.
(When the Chazzan repeats the Shemoneh Esreh, the Kedushah is said here)
text.3_Mincha for Erev Rosh Hashana, 2_Kedush: The Congregation says and the Chazzan repeats:
We will sanctify Your Name in the world,
as is written by the hand of Your prophet,
“And they called one to another, and said:
the fullness of all the earth is His glory.’”
And in Your holy words it is written:
Your God, Tziyon, throughout all generations!
will not depart from our mouths
Who is King; Great, and Holy.
You are holy and Your Name is holy
Cause us to return, our Father, to Your Torah
and bring us near, our King, to Your service;
Pardon us, our Father, for we have sinned,
because You are Forgiver and Pardoner.
for the sake of Your Name;
because You are a Mighty Redeemer.
Heal us, Adonoy, and we will be healed,
deliver us and we will be delivered;
because You are the Almighty, King,
Who is a faithful and merciful Healer.
Healer of the sick of His people Yisrael.
Bless for us, Adonoy our God,
and all the varieties of its produce
upon the face of the earth;
and bless our year like the good years.
Sound the great shofar for our liberty,
and raise a banner to gather our exiles,
from the four corners of the earth.
of the dispersed of His people Yisrael.
and our counselors as at first.
Remove from us sorrow and sighing,
and make us righteous with justice.
King, Lover of righteousness and justice.
For informers let there be no hope
and may all wickedness instantly perish
may all Your enemies be swiftly cut off,
and the insolent may You quickly uproot,
and subdue speedily in our days.
Upon the righteous, upon the pious,
upon the elders of Your people
upon the remnant of their scholars,
upon the true proselytes, and upon us,
to all who trust in Your Name in truth;
and place our lot among them forever
and may we not be put to shame,
for in You we have put our trust,
Support and Trust of the righteous.
and dwell therein as You have spoken;
and rebuild it soon, in our days,
The sprout of Dovid, Your servant,
and exalt his power with Your deliverance,
For Your deliverance we hope all day.
Hear our voice, Adonoy, our God;
spare us and have compassion on us,
and from Your Presence, our King,
do not turn us away empty-handed,
of Your people, Yisrael, with compassion.
to the Holy of Holies in Your abode,
And may You always find pleasure
with the service of Your people, Yisrael.
Who returns His Divine Presence to Tziyon.
At the words, We are thankful, bend forward; at Adonoy return to an upright position.
that You Adonoy are our God
and the God of our fathers forever;
We will give thanks to You
which are committed into Your hand,
and for Your miracles of every day with us,
and for Your wonders and benefactions
for Your compassion is never withheld;
we have always placed our hope in You.
(When the Chazzan repeats the Shemoneh Esreh and says, “Who returns His Divine Presence to Tziyon,” the congregation responds by saying “Amein” and then the following prayer.)
that You Adonoy are our God,
Our Creator, Creator of the Beginning.
to Your great and Holy Name
for keeping us alive, and sustaining us;
so may You always keep us alive
to the Courtyards of Your Sanctuary
for we are thankful to You.
to Whom all thanks are due.
blessed and exalted be Your Name, our King
And all the living shall thank You forever
and praise Your Name with sincerity;
the Almighty, Who is our deliverance
and You it is fitting to praise.
May it be good in Your eyes
at all times and at every moment
My God, guard my tongue from evil
and my lips from speaking deceitfully.
and let my soul be like dust to all.
Open my heart to Your Torah
and let my soul pursue Your commandments.
And all who plan evil against me,
Act for the sake of Your Name.
Act for the sake of Your right hand.
Act for the sake of Your holiness.
Act for the sake of Your Torah.
In order that Your loved ones be released,
deliver [with] Your right hand and answer me.
May the words of my mouth be acceptable
and the thoughts of my heart—before You
Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.
upon us and upon all Yisrael
Adonoy, our God, and the God of our Fathers
that the Holy Temple be rebuilt
and grant us our share in Your Torah.
And there we will serve You reverently
as in the days of old,
with the offerings of Judah and Yerushalayim
as in the days of old and in earlier years.
Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
in the world which He created
and may He rule His Kingdom
in your lifetime and in your days,
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future—
May His great Name be blessed
be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
above all the blessings and hymns,
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
of the entire House of Yisrael
May there be abundant peace from heaven
for us and for all Yisrael,
for us and or all Yisrael,
text.3_Mincha for Erev Rosh Hashana, 3_Aleinu: Kol Bo writes that Joshua authored this prayer when he captured Jericho. Taken from the Musaf service of Rosh Hashana, it serves as the closing prayer of all the daily services. As ruled by Tur (Orach Chaim 133), it is said while standing.
that He has not made us
like the nations of the lands,
like the families of the earth;
nor our lot like that of all their multitudes.
and pray to a god that cannot deliver.
before the Supreme King of kings,
the Holy One blessed is He,
and the seat of His glory is in heaven above,
and the abode of His invincible might
He is our God, there is nothing else.
as it is written in His Torah:
We therefore put our hope in You,
to soon behold the glory of Your might
in banishing idolatry from the earth,
And all mankind will invoke Your Name,
all the wicked of the earth.
all the inhabitants of the world,
that to You, every knee must bend,
every tongue must swear [allegiance to You].
they will bow and prostrate themselves,
and to the glory of Your Name give honor.
And they will all accept [upon themselves]
and You will reign over them, soon,
and to all eternity You will reign in glory,
as it is written in Your Torah:
And it is said: “And Adonoy will be King
on that day Adonoy will be One
text.3_Mincha for Erev Rosh Hashana, 4_Mourne: Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
in the world which He created
and may He rule His Kingdom
in your lifetime and in your days,
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future—
May His great Name be blessed
be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
May there be abundant peace from heaven
and life for us and for all Yisrael,
for us and or all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 0_Paragrap: When Rosh Hashana occurs on either Friday or on Shabbos, the Kabbalas Shabbos service begins here.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 1_Paragrap: A Psalm, a song for the Shabbos day.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 2_Paragrap: It is good to thank1Shabbos, more than other days, lends itself to offering praise and thanksgiving to Hashem. When man rests from his physical labor and is relieved of material concerns, his soul is free to pursue the intellectual and spiritual aspects of life. These pursuits lead him to serve Hashem and to praise Him.—Radak Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 3_Paragrap: and sing praise to Your Name, Most High.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 4_Paragrap: To relate Your kindliness in the morning,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 5_Paragrap: and Your faithfulness in the nights.2We will proclaim His kindliness in the morning of redemption. And while yet in the darkness of exile we proclaim our belief in His faithfulness.—Rashi
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 6_Paragrap: Upon a ten-stringed instrument and lute,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 8_Paragrap: For You have given me joy, Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 10_Paragra: at the work of Your hands3The Shabbos day of rest affords me the opportunity to observe and appreciate the greatness of Your work.—Radak I sing joyously.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 11_Paragra: How great are Your works, Adonoy;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 12_Paragra: how infinitely profound are Your thoughts.4Hashem’s ‘works’ are the visible creation, while His ‘thoughts’ are the Divine purpose behind each created thing.—Seporno
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 14_Paragra: nor does a fool understand this:
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 15_Paragra: When the wicked bloom like grass,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 17_Paragra: it is so that they may be destroyed forever.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 18_Paragra: But You will remain on high forever
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 21_Paragra: For behold, Your enemies shall perish;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 23_Paragra: You uplifted my horn5Others translate, ‘You have increased my might like that of the wild ram.’ like that of a unicorn;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 24_Paragra: I am saturated with fresh oil.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 25_Paragra: My eye has seen [the defeat of]
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 27_Paragra: of the wicked who rise against me,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 28_Paragra: my ears have heard [that they are doomed].
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 29_Paragra: The righteous will blossom like a date palm,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 30_Paragra: like a cedar6The palm and the cedar both enjoy a long life span and flourish during all seasons. Thus they symbolize the lasting happiness of the righteous in contrast to the short prosperity of the wicked. in Lebanon, he will grow tall.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 31_Paragra: Planted in the House of Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 32_Paragra: in the courtyards of our God
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 34_Paragra: They will still be fruitful in old age;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 35_Paragra: they will be full of sap and freshness.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 36_Paragra: To declare that Adonoy is upright;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 38_Paragra: in Whom there is no injustice.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 40_Paragra: He has clothed Himself with majesty;
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 42_Paragra: He has girded Himself with strength.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 43_Paragra: He has firmly established the world
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 44_Paragra: so that it cannot be moved.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 45_Paragra: Your throne stands firm from of old,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 48_Paragra: the rivers have raised their voice,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 49_Paragra: the rivers raise their raging waves.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 50_Paragra: More than the sound of many waters,
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 51_Paragra: mightier than the breakers of the sea
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 52_Paragra: Mighty on high, are You, Adonoy.
text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 54_Paragra: holiness is becoming to Your House,

text.4_Maariv, 0_Kabbalas Shabbos, 82_Paragra: for us and or all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 2_Paragraph: The congregation responds and the Chazzan repeats:
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 6_Paragraph: our God, King of the Universe,
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 9_Paragraph: with wisdom He opens the gates1These are the gates of sunrise and sunset through which Hashem, in His infinite wisdom, has divided life on earth into two complementary halves.—Rabbi S.R. Hirsch (of heaven);
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 10_Paragraph: and with understanding changes2He alternates the three daily periods—evening, morning, and afternoon.—Avudraham the times
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 13_Paragraph: in their watches,3The stars appear as watchmen appointed by Hashem to stand guard over the sleeping world below. He also appointed them their places in definite orbits according to His will and for purposes known to Him alone.—S.R. Hirsch in the sky,
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 16_Paragraph: He rolls the light away from before darkness,
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 20_Paragraph: and separates between day and night;
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 21_Paragraph: Adonoy of Hosts4His Name ה' צְבָאוֹת means “He Who takes all the infinite variety of hosts and creatures and unites them to act and interact as parts of one unified Universe.—S.R. Hirsch is His Name.
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 28_Paragraph: [With] an everlasting love5This prayer is an abbreviated form of the אַהֲבָה רַבָּה prayer in the morning service. It thanks Hashem for the sacred gift of Divine Revelation that He granted Yisrael. It declares that Torah alone is the eternal heritage of the Jewish people and that all other goods and gifts of life are transitory.—S.R. Hirsch
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 29_Paragraph: You loved the House of Yisrael, Your people.

text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 151_Paragraph: —and faithful is all this,6All that we have affirmed in the Shema, is true and trustworthy.—Etz Yosef

text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 182_Paragraph: to everlasting12The redemption from Egypt is the source for all later redemptions; it is the source from which our final and total salvation will spring. We became free, never again to taste the bitterness of spiritual or physical bondage.—Sfas Emes freedom.

text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 211_Paragraph: Adonoy our God; make us lie down in peace,17Undisturbed peace, and strength for a new day of vigorous living are the gifts that night brings and for which we pray to Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 215_Paragraph: and direct us to better ourselves
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 216_Paragraph: through Your good counsel;18We particularly ask of Him at night to bless us with wise counsel. Daytime is the time for achievement, but the rest that comes with nightfall is made to allow man to compose his thoughts. By virtue of the complete relaxation it affords, sleep endows the mind and spirit with renewed vigor. We pray therefore for Divine aid so that our nightly rest will help us take wise counsel and affirm worthy resolution for future days.—Avudraham and Siach Yitzchak
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 217_Paragraph: and deliver us for Your Name’s sake.
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 218_Paragraph: Shield us, and remove from us19Shield us from trouble before it comes, and remove it from us if it has already come.—Siach Yitzchak
text.4_Maariv, 1_Borechu, 221_Paragraph: Remove the adversary20The Hebrew word שָׂטָן (Satan) used in the Prayer Book refers to the Evil Impulse, the lower passions which are a hindrance to man’s pursuit of the nobler aims in life. It is against the dominance of this impulse that the Jew prays. The “adversary,” therefore, is any person, spirit, or Evil Impulse that seduces us to do wrong.—Dover Sholom and others from before us

text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 1_Paragraph: and my mouth will declare Your praise.24Rabbi Yonasan Eibschitz in his sefer, Yaaros Devash, explains that upon reflecting in Whose presence he is about to pray, man should be so overwhelmed with awe and trepidation that he is unable to open his lips. He therefore prefaces his prayer by beseeching Hashem, to open his lips, asking His help to be able to pray in His Presence.

text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 16_Paragraph: Remember us for life25Because these are days of judgment and our lives hang in the balance, we pray to Hashem to remember us for life (Rashi, Levush).

text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 48_Paragraph: You are holy and Your Name is holy
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 51_Paragraph: And so,36The word וּבְכֵן, ‘and so,’ marks the beginning of the special prayers of the Shemoneh Esreh recited at each Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur service. According to Avudraham, the Sages chose this word to convey the thought expressed by Esther as she prepared to go before the king on behalf of her people. After telling Mordechai to assemble all the Jews to fast for three days and nights on her behalf, she said, “ וּבְכֵן אָבוֹא אֶל הַמֶּלֶךְ ‘and so I will go in to the king” (Esther 4:16). Thus, since today is the Day of Judgment, as we come before the Supreme King of kings, the Holy One Blessed is He, we begin with the words uttered by Esther as she came before the king. The Siddur Maggid Tzedek quoted by Siach Yitzchak writes that the emphasis of Avudraham was on the last words of the verse said by Esther, “וּבְכֵן אָבוֹא אֶל הַמֶּלֶךְ אֲשֶׁר לֹא כַדָּת,” “And so I will go into the king, even if it is unlawful,” for which one of us can say, “I am virtuous, I have cleansed my heart from sin.” Especially on this great and awesome Day of Judgment, who among us is not embarrassed and ashamed to appear before the King of kings garbed in sackcloths of sin. If Esther who had fasted for three days in penitence and prayer in preparation for her appearance before the king was nevertheless so terribly frightened that she declared: “וּבְכֵן אָבוֹא אֶל הַמֶּלֶךְ אֲשֶׁר לֹא כַדָּת” then we should certainly tremble in awe before the presence of Hashem on this Day of Judgment, knowing deep in our hearts how little and how poorly we have prepared ourselves. Thus our Sages ordained that we open the prayers with the word וּבְכֵן recalling the words of Esther; therewith shattering our delusiouns of spiritual complacency, and causing us to bow before Him with broken hearts and tear-filled eyes.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 52_Paragraph: grant37The word תֵּן implies מַתָּנָה, a gift. We ask Hashem to grant us the feeling of reverence for Him, as a gift, knowing how difficult it is to attain such a high level of reverence completely on our own (Siach Yitzchak). that Your awe, Adonoy, our God,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 53_Paragraph: be upon all Your works,38The word מַעֲשֶׂיךָ, lit., Your works, indicates that which has attained or is near perfection. Thus Yisrael is called His works since we have accepted His kingship and His Torah which is the fulfillment of Hashem’s creation (Siach Yitzchak).
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 54_Paragraph: and Your dread upon all You have created;39All you have created, שֶׁבָּרָאתָ, indicates that which has not attained its fulfillment, thus we ask Hashem to cast His dread even on those people who have not yet accepted His Divine Kingdom (Siach Yitzchak).
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 55_Paragraph: and [then] all [Your] works will fear You,40The nation of Yisrael will fear You.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 57_Paragraph: will be all [Your] created beings.41The nations of the world will finally prostrate themselves before You, i.e. submit to You and accept the yoke of Your Kingship.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 58_Paragraph: And may they all form a single band
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 61_Paragraph: For we know Adonoy, our God
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 64_Paragraph: might is in Your right hand
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 68_Paragraph: grant honor, Adonoy, to Your people,42Once all of Your works and created beings have submitted themselves to Your rule and formed a single bond to do Your will, the honor of Yisrael will be established and raised to new heights. It will then be apparent to all that Yisrael alone carried the yoke of Hashem’s kingdom throughout the bitter years of exile, giving Him obedience despite its suffering and persecution and the taunts of those who cynically asked, “Where is Your God” (Etz Yosef).
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 69_Paragraph: praise to those who fear You,43Those who fear Hashem will then be praiseworthy in the eyes of all men.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 70_Paragraph: good hope to those who seek You44Men will no longer consider as ridiculous those who seek Hashem and search for ways to serve Him.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 72_Paragraph: to those who yearn for You,45Those who wait upon Him will no longer be subdued but will voice their convictions freely.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 73_Paragraph: joy to Your land, gladness to Your city,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 74_Paragraph: flourishing of pride to Dovid, Your servant
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 76_Paragraph: to the son of Yishai, Your anointed,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 77_Paragraph: speedily in our days.46See Tehillim 132:17. The climax of this spiritual renaissance will be the restoration of our people to our land under the scepter of the Moshiach, descendant of Dovid, the anointed of Hashem.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 79_Paragraph: the righteous will see [this] and rejoice,47The entire universe was created for the sake of Yisrael in order that Hashem’s Divine Influence be attached to it. This essence (Yisrael) was created for the sake of an even more treasured essence, namely the prophets and the pious among them. This gradation forms the basis of the sequence of the Rosh Hashana-Yom Kippur prayers: “Grant that Your awe be upon all that You have made,” is the first prayer. It is followed by, “Grant honor to Your people,” and finally by “the righteous will see this and rejoice.” Thus the righteous and pious are the purpose and fulfillment of the entire creation, the true reason for celebrating these holy days (Fundamentals of Kuzari, page 59).

text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 184_Paragraph: Our God and God of our fathers,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 186_Paragraph: with Your glory,48Our plea to Hashem is, “let Your rule become evident in all Your glory.” Hashem has reigned supreme at all times; it is only man who, until now, has failed to recognize Hashem’s rule and render Him homage. We now pray that man will at long last come to know Hashem’s eternal, universal sovereignty and pay it the tribute of unreserved obedience (S.R. Hirsch).
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 187_Paragraph: and be uplifted over all the earth
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 190_Paragraph: in the splendor of Your majestic might
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 192_Paragraph: in the inhabited world of Your earth;
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 193_Paragraph: so everything that has been made will know
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 199_Paragraph: everyone who has breath in his nostrils,49According to Avudraham this classification refers to the very wicked who have never fulfilled a commandment, but who nevertheless have breath in their nostrils. Let them also proclaim on the Day of Judgment, that You, God of Yisrael are King!
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 201_Paragraph: and His Kingship rules over all.”
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 203_Paragraph: (Our God and God of our fathers,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 206_Paragraph: and give us our share in Your Torah;
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 208_Paragraph: and gladden us with Your deliverance,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 215_Paragraph: [they who are] sanctifiers of Your Name)
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 216_Paragraph: and purify our hearts to serve You in truth,50Even as Hashem Himself is forever true, and even as His word, the Torah and the promise revealed to us are eternally true and unalterable, so too our own service to Him should be true, unswerving and constant. For this purpose we pray for טַהֲרַת הַלֵּב, purity of heart. We must cleanse and purify our hearts of every passion and impulse that might tempt us to transgress the law or that might stand in the way of our serving Hashem (S.R. Hirsch).
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 217_Paragraph: for You are the true God,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 218_Paragraph: and Your word is true and enduring forever.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 224_Paragraph: of Yisrael and the Day of Remembrance.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 230_Paragraph: to the Holy of Holies in Your abode,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 234_Paragraph: And may You always find pleasure
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 235_Paragraph: with the service of Your people, Yisrael.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 239_Paragraph: Who returns His Divine Presence to Tziyon.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 240_Paragraph: At the words, We are thankful, bend forward; at Adonoy return to an upright position.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 243_Paragraph: that You Adonoy are our God
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 244_Paragraph: and the God of our fathers forever;
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 248_Paragraph: We will give thanks to You
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 251_Paragraph: which are committed into Your hand,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 256_Paragraph: and for Your wonders and benefactions
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 260_Paragraph: for Your compassion is never withheld;
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 263_Paragraph: we have always placed our hope in You.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 269_Paragraph: all the children of Your covenant.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 270_Paragraph: If you forgot to say this, you need not go back and repeat the Amidah. If you became aware of the omission before concluding the blessing, you can say it at that time.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 271_Paragraph: And all the living shall thank You forever
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 274_Paragraph: the Almighty, Who is our deliverance
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 278_Paragraph: and You it is fitting to praise.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 285_Paragraph: And may it be good in Your eyes
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 288_Paragraph: at all times and at every moment
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 290_Paragraph: In the book of life, blessing, peace
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 292_Paragraph: may we be remembered and inscribed
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 294_Paragraph: we and all Your people, the House of Yisrael
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 295_Paragraph: for a good life and peace.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 296_Paragraph: If you forgot to say this, you need not go back and repeat the Amidah.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 302_Paragraph: May the words of my mouth be acceptable
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 303_Paragraph: and the thoughts of my heart—before You
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 304_Paragraph: Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 307_Paragraph: and my lips from speaking deceitfully.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 310_Paragraph: and let my soul be like dust to all.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 311_Paragraph: Open my heart to Your Torah
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 312_Paragraph: and let my soul pursue Your commandments.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 313_Paragraph: And all who plan evil against me,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 316_Paragraph: Act for the sake of Your Name.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 317_Paragraph: Act for the sake of Your right hand.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 318_Paragraph: Act for the sake of Your holiness.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 319_Paragraph: Act for the sake of Your Torah.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 320_Paragraph: In order that Your loved ones be released,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 321_Paragraph: deliver [with] Your right hand and answer me.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 322_Paragraph: May the words of my mouth be acceptable
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 323_Paragraph: and the thoughts of my heart—before You
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 324_Paragraph: Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 325_Paragraph: He Who makes the peace in His high heavens
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 327_Paragraph: upon us and upon all Yisrael
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 330_Paragraph: Adonoy, our God, and the God of our Fathers
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 331_Paragraph: that the Holy Temple be rebuilt
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 333_Paragraph: and grant us our share in Your Torah.
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 334_Paragraph: And there we will serve You reverently
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 335_Paragraph: as in the days of old,
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 338_Paragraph: with the offerings of Judah and Yerushalayim
text.4_Maariv, 2_Amidah, 339_Paragraph: as in the days of old and in earlier years.
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 0_Paragraph: When Rosh Hashana falls on Shabbos, the entire congregation repeats וַיְכֻלּוּ, in testimony of our belief that God created Heaven and earth. According to the Halacha, when one is a witness, he must stand and declare his testimony aloud.
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 1_Paragraph: The heavens and the earth were completed
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 3_Paragraph: And God completed by the seventh day
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 4_Paragraph: His work which He had done,
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 5_Paragraph: and He abstained on the seventh day,
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 6_Paragraph: from all His work which He had done.
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 7_Paragraph: And God blessed the seventh day
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 11_Paragraph: which God had created to do.
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 12_Paragraph: The following prayer, בְּרָכָה מֵעֵין שֶׁבַע the abridged form of the seven blessings of the Maariv Amidah, is said only by the Chazzan.
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 14_Paragraph: our God and God of our fathers,
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 15_Paragraph: God of Avraham, God of Yitzchak,
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 18_Paragraph: the Great, the Powerful, the Awesome,
text.4_Maariv, 3_Vayechulu, 21_Paragraph: The congregation may recite the following paragraph, which should then be repeated aloud and in its entirety by the Chazzan.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 0_Paragraph: Shield of [our] fathers with His word,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 5_Paragraph: He gives rest to His people
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 6_Paragraph: on the day of His holy Shabbos
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 7_Paragraph: for with them He was pleased
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 11_Paragraph: and give thanks to His Name
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 13_Paragraph: from the essence of the blessings.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 19_Paragraph: to a people sated with delight—
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 20_Paragraph: in commemoration of the work of creation.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 21_Paragraph: Our God, and God of our fathers,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 24_Paragraph: and give us our share in Your Torah;
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 26_Paragraph: and gladden us with Your deliverance,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 27_Paragraph: and purify our hearts to serve You in truth.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 28_Paragraph: And give us as our inheritance,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 38_Paragraph: the earth is Adonoy’s and the fullness thereof,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 40_Paragraph: and those who dwell in it.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 41_Paragraph: For He founded it upon the seas,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 43_Paragraph: Who may ascend the mountain of Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 45_Paragraph: in the place of His holiness?
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 46_Paragraph: The clean of hands and the pure of heart,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 47_Paragraph: who has not borne My soul in vain,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 51_Paragraph: from the God of his deliverance.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 52_Paragraph: This is the generation of those who seek Him,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 58_Paragraph: so that the King of Glory may enter.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 59_Paragraph: Who is this King of Glory?
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 61_Paragraph: Adonoy, the Mighty One in battle.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 63_Paragraph: and lift up, entranceways to eternity,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 64_Paragraph: so that the King of Glory may enter.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 65_Paragraph: Who is He, this King of Glory?
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 67_Paragraph: He is the King of Glory, selah.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 69_Paragraph: Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 70_Paragraph: in the world which He created
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 72_Paragraph: and may He rule His Kingdom
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 73_Paragraph: in your lifetime and in your days,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 75_Paragraph: of the entire House of Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 76_Paragraph: speedily and in the near future—
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 78_Paragraph: May His great Name be blessed
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 83_Paragraph: be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 87_Paragraph: which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 90_Paragraph: of the entire House of Yisrael
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 93_Paragraph: May there be abundant peace from heaven
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 95_Paragraph: for us and for all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 4_Magein Avos, 100_Paragraph: for us and or all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 5_Paragraph: that He has not made us
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 6_Paragraph: like the nations of the lands,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 8_Paragraph: like the families of the earth;
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 11_Paragraph: nor our lot like that of all their multitudes.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 14_Paragraph: and pray to a god that cannot deliver.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 17_Paragraph: before the Supreme King of kings,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 18_Paragraph: the Holy One blessed is He,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 21_Paragraph: and the seat of His glory is in heaven above,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 22_Paragraph: and the abode of His invincible might
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 24_Paragraph: He is our God, there is nothing else.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 27_Paragraph: as it is written in His Torah:
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 34_Paragraph: We therefore put our hope in You,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 36_Paragraph: to soon behold the glory of Your might
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 37_Paragraph: in banishing idolatry from the earth,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 42_Paragraph: And all mankind will invoke Your Name,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 44_Paragraph: all the wicked of the earth.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 46_Paragraph: all the inhabitants of the world,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 47_Paragraph: that to You, every knee must bend,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 48_Paragraph: every tongue must swear [allegiance to You].
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 50_Paragraph: they will bow and prostrate themselves,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 51_Paragraph: and to the glory of Your Name give honor.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 52_Paragraph: And they will all accept [upon themselves]
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 54_Paragraph: and You will reign over them, soon,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 57_Paragraph: and to all eternity You will reign in glory,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 58_Paragraph: as it is written in Your Torah:
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 63_Paragraph: on that day Adonoy will be One
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 65_Paragraph: Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 66_Paragraph: in the world which He created
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 68_Paragraph: and may He rule His Kingdom
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 69_Paragraph: in your lifetime and in your days,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 71_Paragraph: of the entire House of Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 72_Paragraph: speedily and in the near future—
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 74_Paragraph: May His great Name be blessed
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 79_Paragraph: be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 83_Paragraph: which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 84_Paragraph: May there be abundant peace from heaven
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 86_Paragraph: for us and for all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 91_Paragraph: for us and or all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 93_Paragraph: The following Psalm (27) is recited at the conclusion of services, morning and evenings, from the first day of Elul, through Shemini Atzeres.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 94_Paragraph: The Psalm voices our prayer that God will be our light on Rosh Hashana enabling us to repel the darkness of sin through true repentance, and that He will be our salvation on Yom Kippur, through His compassionate atonement of our sins.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 96_Paragraph: Adonoy is my light and my salvation,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 98_Paragraph: Adonoy is the strength51Rav S.R. Hirsch’s translates, “Adonoy is the source of my life’s strength,” thus Dovid declares that Hashem is the fount from which his life derives its power to resist all foes. of my life,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 99_Paragraph: of whom shall I be afraid?
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 104_Paragraph: If an army should encamp against me,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 106_Paragraph: if war were to rise against me
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 107_Paragraph: in this52Dovid says that he trusts in the declaration stated in the opening verse, “Adonoy is my light and my salvation; whom shall I fear?”—Rashi, Radak I trust.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 108_Paragraph: One thing I request of Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 110_Paragraph: that I may dwell53The literal translation of שִׁבְתִּי is “my sitting.” The Talmud states that “no man may ‘sit’ in the courtyard of the Temple except for the kings of the House of Dovid.—Maseches Soteh 40b in the House of Adonoy
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 111_Paragraph: all the days of my life,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 112_Paragraph: to behold the pleasantness of Adonoy,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 113_Paragraph: and to meditate in His Sanctuary.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 114_Paragraph: For He will hide me in His Tabernacle54The Vilna Gaon comments that the commandment of Succos is implied in this verse and the next.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 116_Paragraph: He will conceal me in the shelter of His Tent,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 117_Paragraph: upon a rock He will lift me.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 118_Paragraph: And now my head is raised high
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 119_Paragraph: above my enemies around me;55Dovid declares, “Because I look up to Hashem in every aspect of my existence, I am so exalted that no enemy can harm me.—S.R. Hirsch
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 120_Paragraph: and I will offer in His Tent,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 122_Paragraph: I will sing and chant to Adonoy.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 123_Paragraph: Adonoy, hear my voice56This verse alludes to Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur. “Hear my voice,” refers to Rosh Hashana when we sound the shofar. The word “my voice (sound)” refers to the “voice” of the shofar. “When I call” refers to Yom Kippur, about which Yeshaya (55:6) said, “call to Him when He is near.”—Siddur HaGra when I call;
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 124_Paragraph: be gracious to me and answer me.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 125_Paragraph: Of You, my heart has said,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 127_Paragraph: Your Presence, Adonoy I will seek.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 128_Paragraph: Conceal not Your Presence from me,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 129_Paragraph: do not turn away Your servant in anger.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 131_Paragraph: neither cast me off nor abandon me,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 134_Paragraph: abandon57Even if I were so depraved that my own mother and father would abandon me to my own devices, Hashem would still gather me up and believe in my ability to mend my ways.—S.R. Hirsch me,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 137_Paragraph: and lead me in the path of uprightness,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 138_Paragraph: because of my watchful foes.58His enemies. Dovid asks for Divine help that he be saved even from the mere semblance of wrongdoing so that his foes should not be able to rejoice over his faults.—S.R. Hirsch
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 140_Paragraph: to the will of my tormentors,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 141_Paragraph: for false witnesses have risen against me,
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 143_Paragraph: Had I not believed59“These false witnesses would have destroyed me had I not believed that I would see the goodness of Hashem in the land of the living.”—Rashi, Radak that I would see
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 145_Paragraph: in the land of living.60There are various interpretations of the “Land of the living.” Some hold that it refers to the present world in which we live—Metsudas Tziyon; Ramban holds that it refers to the World-to- Come; and Malbim says that it refers to Eretz Yisroel.
text.4_Maariv, 5_Aleinu, 147_Paragraph: be strong and He will give you courage;
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 0_Paragra: Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 1_Paragra: in the world which He created
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 3_Paragra: and may He rule His Kingdom
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 4_Paragra: in your lifetime and in your days,
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 6_Paragra: of the entire House of Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 7_Paragra: speedily and in the near future—
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 9_Paragra: May His great Name be blessed
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 14_Paragr: be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 18_Paragr: which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 19_Paragr: May there be abundant peace from heaven
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 21_Paragr: for us and for all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 23_Paragr: He Who makes the peace in His high heavens
text.4_Maariv, 6_Mourner's Kaddish, 25_Paragr: for us and or all Yisrael,
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 0_Paragraph: This hymn has been attributed to R’ Shlomo ibn Gabirol who lived in Spain during the eleventh century.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 3_Paragraph: At the time when all was made by His will,
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 4_Paragraph: then was His Name proclaimed King.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 5_Paragraph: And after all things shall cease to be,
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 6_Paragraph: the Awesome One will reign alone.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 8_Paragraph: and He shall be in glory.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 9_Paragraph: He is One, and there is no second
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 10_Paragraph: to compare to Him, to associate [with Him].
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 13_Paragraph: He is my God and my ever-living Redeemer,
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 14_Paragraph: the Rock of my destiny in times of distress.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 15_Paragraph: He is my flag and my refuge;
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 16_Paragraph: He is the portion of my cup on the day I call.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 17_Paragraph: Into His hand I entrust my spirit
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 18_Paragraph: [both] when I sleep and when I awaken.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 19_Paragraph: And with my spirit my body [too],
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 20_Paragraph: Adonoy is with me, I shall not fear.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 21_Paragraph: After the services it is customary to greet friends with the following greeting
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 23_Paragraph: May you be inscribed for a good year.
text.4_Maariv, 7_Adon Olam, 25_Paragraph: May you be inscribed for a good year.
text.5_Kiddush, 0_Paragraph: When Rosh Hashana occurs on Shabbos, begin here:
text.5_Kiddush, 2_Paragraph: And evening came, then morning came:
text.5_Kiddush, 5_Paragraph: The heavens and the earth were completed
text.5_Kiddush, 7_Paragraph: And God completed, by the seventh day,
text.5_Kiddush, 8_Paragraph: His work which He had done;
text.5_Kiddush, 9_Paragraph: and He abstained on the seventh day
text.5_Kiddush, 10_Paragraph: from all His work which He had done.
text.5_Kiddush, 11_Paragraph: And God blessed the seventh day
text.5_Kiddush, 15_Paragraph: which God had created to do.
text.5_Kiddush, 18_Paragraph: Attention! our masters and our teachers:

text.5_Kiddush, 86_Paragraph: On the first night of Rosh Hashana, it is customary to perform several symbolic rituals, to serve as good omens for the coming new year. At the beginning of the evening meal it is customary to dip a portion of the challah in honey and after eating a piece, the weight of an olive, say: “יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְפָנֶיךָ שֶׁתְּחַדֵשׁ עָלֵינוּ שָׁנָה טוֹבָה וּמְתוּקָה—May it be Your will to renew for us a good and sweet year.” Then, take a piece of sweet apple and dip it in honey. First make the blessing, “בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה' אֱלֹהֵֽינוּ מֶֽלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ—Blessed are You, Adonoy, our God, King of the universe, Who creates the fruit of the tree.” After tasting it, repeat the above prayer, “יְהִי רָצוֹן—May it be Your will to renew for us a good and sweet year.” It is also a custom to eat a piece of the head of some animal, (preferably a sheep) and say: “יְהִי רָצוֹן שֶׁנִהְיֶה לְראשׁ—May it be Your will that we be at the head.” We also eat certain vegetables, the names of which convey the connotations of good fortune, such as carrots which in Yiddish are called mehren (increase), and we say: “יְהִי רָצוֹן שֶׁיִרְבּוּ זְכוּיוֹתֵינוּ—May it be Your will that our merits increase.”
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 0_Upon Arising in: Upon waking in the morning, even before washing your hands, say:
for You have restored my soul with mercy.
The beginning of wisdom is fear of Adonoy,
Before putting on your tallis katan say:
our God, King of the Universe
Who sanctified us with His commandments
Adonoy, my God, and God of my fathers,
the mitzva of tzitzis before You
as though I had fulfilled it

and the 6131The numerical value of the word צִיצִית is 600 which, with the 8 threads and 5 knots of the צִיצִית itself, makes 613, the exact number of the mitzvos of the Torah. This symbolizes the Talmudic statement (Maseches Nedarim 25a) that the wearing of tzitzis equals the observance of the whole Torah. commandments
that depend on it. Amein, Selah.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 1_Putting On the: While examining the fringes of the tallis say:
My soul, bless Adonoy,
Adonoy, my God, You are greatly exalted.
With beauty and splendor are You clothed
enwrapped in light, garment-like;
You spread out the heavens like a curtain.2Tehillim 104:1,2.
Blessed are You, Adonoy
our God, King of the Universe,
Who sanctified us with His commandments
and commanded us
to enwrap ourselves with tzitzis.
Cover your head with the tallis and say:
How precious is Your kindness, God;
the children of men
take refuge in the shadow of Your wings.
They will be filled
from the abundance of Your House,
and from the stream of Your delights
You will give them to drink.
For with You is the source of life,
in Your light shall we see light.
Extend Your kindness
to those who know You,
and Your righteousness
to the upright in heart.3Tehillim 36:8-11.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 2_Ma Tovu, 0_Para: The following verses from Scriptures are recited upon entering the synagogue, as though asking permission of God to enter and pray in His Holy place.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 2_Ma Tovu, 2_Para: your dwelling places, Yisrael.4Bamidbar 24:5. The Talmud (Maseches Sanhedrin 105a) relates that this verse contains Bilam’s prophetic allusion to Jewish houses of study and worship.

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 3_Adon Olam, 0_Pa: This hymn has been attributed to R’ Shlomo ibn Gabirol who lived in Spain during the eleventh century. While praising God’s omnipotence and providence, it clarifies the meaning of the name Adonoy so that before proceeding to pray, each worshiper understands the significance of the God he is addressing.

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 4_Yigdal, 0_Parag: This hymn, written by Daniel ben Yehuda, who was a Dayan in Rome about 1300, is based on Maimonides’ 13 principles of Judaism. According to Maimonides, failure to believe in a single one of these principles places one outside the pale of Judaism.

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 4_Yigdal, 43_Para: according to his wickedness.12The word deed is not applied to the wicked man. Since Divine reward and punishment are distributed with kindness, reward is granted to man not only for his deed which may itself be insignificant, but also for the long range effect of that deed. He is punished, however, only for his act of wickedness, not for the consequences of his deed.—Etz Yosef

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 5_Blessings Upon: Blessed13The word “blessed” is similar in concept to the words: “merciful” or “gracious” when applied to Hashem. Just as merciful means that He is merciful, the source of mercy; so too, blessed means that He is the source of blessing.—Avudraham are You, Adonoy14Generally speaking, the name Adonoy is understood as it is pronounced—Adonoy—my Master, and indicates His rule and providence of the universe. When reciting the Shema however, one should bear in mind the written character of the Name which indicates Hashem’s everpresent existence. He was—is—and ever will be.—Vilna Gaon
our God, King of the Universe,
Who sanctified us with His commandments
our God, King of the Universe,
Who formed man with wisdom15This may mean either that man was formed by Hashem’s wisdom, or that Hashem formed man and endowed him with wisdom.

in the presence of Your glorious throne16In refutation of those who claim that Hashem is not concerned with earthly matters, we declare that even in the presence of His glorious throne, where He is surrounded by myriads of angels, He is aware of the mundane needs of each individual.—Vilna Gaon
that if one of them were ruptured,

it would be impossible to exist
the soul which You bestowed in me is pure;

You will eventually take it from me,
and restore it in me in the time to come.17This statement refers to the time when the dead will be resurrected.
So long as the soul is within me
I give thanks to You, Adonoy my God,18Thus it is said, “I will praise Adonoy with my life, I will sing to my God with my being” (Tehillim 146:2).
to dead bodies.19This is a reference to Hashem’s restoring of the soul each morning following its departure while the person sleeps.

Who sanctified20The observance and fulfillment of His commandments makes a person holy. us

Who teaches Torah to His people, Yisrael.
our God, King of the Universe

[of a field unharvested],25The unharvested produce was left for the poor; Vayikra 19:9.

the appearance-offering,27These offerings were brought when a Jew “appeared” before Hashem in the Temple on the three Pilgrimage festivals—Pesach, Shavuos and Sukkos—Shemos 23:14-17, Devarim 16:16,17.
the fruits of which man enjoys
is preserved for him in the World-to-Come.
early attendance in the House of Study
concentrating on the meaning of prayers,
and the study of Torah is equal to them all.

into the grasp of sin,30To sin unknowingly.

or brought to disgrace.33Should we fail the tests, we will be disgraced.

favor,34“Favor” means receiving Hashem’s blessings because of our merit.—Si’ach Yitzchak kindness,35“Kindness” is Hashem’s benevolence bestowed purely by His will, regardless of merit.—Si’ach Yitzchak and compassion36“Compassion” describes Hashem’s withholding of deserved punishment.—Si’ach Yitzchak

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 8_Akeidah (The Bi: Our God and God of our fathers,
and be mindful of us for
Remember in our behalf, Adonoy, our God:
Avraham, Yitzchak, and Yisrael, Your servants;
and the oath which You swore
to our father Avraham on Mount Moriah,
as it is written in Your Torah.37Bereishis 22:1-19:
After these events,38These events refer to the previous nine tests by which Hashem tested Avraham. This was to be the tenth and the most difficult test of all.—Ha’amek Dovor
your only one,39Yitzchak was Avraham’s only son by Sarah.
and go to the land of Moriah,
and bring him up as a burnt-offering
which I will designate to you.
Avraham awoke early in the morning,
and took his two attendants40Yishmael and Eliezer.—Rashi with him,
He split the wood of the burnt-offering,
and rose up, and went to the place
that God had designated to him.
and saw the place from afar.
and I and the boy will go to that place.
and return41Avraham prophesied that both of them would return.—Rashi to you.”
and placed it on his son Yitzchak.

the fire and the knife,42The Hebrew word is “maacheles” (root: אכל = to eat) which means that it renders meat fit for eating through slaughtering the animal. Another interpretation is: his knife is called maacheles because we still enjoy (eat) the reward of Avraham’s virtue when he agreed to use it to slaughter his son.—Rashi
Yitzchak spoke to Avraham his father
and he said, “Here I am my son.”
He said, “Here are the fire and the wood,
but where is the lamb for the burnt-offering?”
for a burnt offering, my son.”
And the two of them went together.43Although Yitzchak understood that he was going to be slaughtered, “They went together”— with like hearts.—Rashi
that God had designated to him,

and Avraham built the44The Torah says that he built “the” altar not just “an” altar, to indicate that Avraham rebuilt the same altar which was originally built by Adam and used by Kayin, Hevel and by No’ach.—Targum Yonoson ben Uziel altar there,
and placed him on the altar,
An angel of Adonoy called to him
that you are one who fears God
and have not withheld your son,
and beheld a ram45Tradition tells us that this ram was prepared for this purpose from the time of creation. Rashi (from Maseches Avos 5:6)
after it had been caught in the thicket
and Avraham went and took the ram,
and brought it up as a burnt-offering

“Adonoy will see”;46The Midrash interprets the following: “Hashem will see the binding of Yitzchak and through its merit He will pardon Yisrael every year and rescue them from trouble. It will thus be said, “On this day,” by all generations that the ashes of Yitzchak are seen by Hashem and serve as our atonement.—Rashi
as it is said [to] this day
“On Adonoy’s mountain, He will be seen.”
An angel of Adonoy called to Avraham
a second time from heaven, and said,
“‘I have sworn by Myself,’ declares Adonoy,

and make your descendants as numerous47If these blessings were intended to increase the population of Avraham’s descendants, it was superfluous, since Hashem had previously blessed him for that purpose. Hashem here blessed the descendants of Avraham with the nobility of spirit and courage to fulfill the command to sanctify Hashem even when self-sacrifice is required. Only the nation of Yisrael, Avraham’s children, were commanded to fulfill this mitzvoh, because of the legacy we inherited from him.—Ha’amek Dovor.
as the stars of the sky
and like the sand on the seashore,
Through your children, will be blessed
all the nations of the world,
and they rose and went together
and Avraham dwelt in Beer Sheva.
Adonoy, our God and God of our fathers,
Just as our father, Avraham suppressed
his compassion for his only son
over Your [other] attributes,48This refers to Hashem’s attribute of stern justice.
more leniently than the letter of Your law.
Deal with us, Adonoy, our God,
from Your people, and from Your city,
Fulfill for us, Adonoy, our God,
through Your servant Moshe, as was said,49Vayikra 26:42.
“I will recall My covenant with Yaakov,
and also My covenant with Avraham
and I will recall the land.”
A person should always be in fear of God,

privately as well as openly,50Some people conduct themselves in a God-fearing manner in the presence of others (in public), but in the privacy of their homes, do whatever they please. There are others who do just the opposite. In private they are governed by fear of Hashem, but in the presence of others they are too embarrassed or intimidated to be God-fearing. A Jew must always fear Hashem, in private as well as in public.—Si’ach Yitzchak

[he should] admit the truth,51Acknowledging the truth is fundamental to serving Hashem, and to all human behavior. One who is concerned merely with “winning the argument” will go to any extreme to come out on top. This attitude caused the downfall of the 250 leaders who joined Korach, rather than acknowledge the truth of Moshe’ declaration (Bamidbar 16:2-35).—Si’ach Yitzchak

and speak truth in his heart,52It is not sufficient to merely acknowledge the truth verbally but one must speak truth in his heart as well. Rashi on the Talmud (Maseches Makos 24a) cites the following incident as an example of how one should speak truth in his heart: A buyer once offered to purchase an article from Rav Safra while he was reciting the Shema. Because he could not indicate his acceptance, the anxious purchaser increased his offer. Rav Safra refused the increment because in his heart he had already accepted the original offer.
Not on account of our righteousness
do we offer our supplications before You,
but on account of Your abundant mercy.
What are we? What is our life?
What are our acts of kindness?
What is our deliverance?53Of ourselves or others.
What is our strength? What is our might?
What can we say before You,
Adonoy, our God and God of our fathers?
Are not all the mighty men
Famous men as though they had never been?
The wise as if they were without knowledge?
as if they were devoid of intelligence?
For most of their actions are a waste,54In terms of achievement.—Dover Sholom
and the days of their life
are trivial55In terms of time.—Dover Sholom in Your presence.
The superiority of man over the beast
children of Avraham, Your beloved,56Others translate, “Children of Avraham who loved You.” See commentaries on Yeshaya 41:8.
to whom You swore on Mount Moriah;
the seed of Yitzchak, his only son,
who was bound on top of the altar;
the community of Yaakov, Your firstborn,
and Your joyous delight in him—

You named him Yisrael57The name Yisrael symbolizes Yaakov’s wandering through history proclaiming the sovereignty of Hashem, while the name Yeshurun indicates his task to fulfill Hashem’s will as revealed to him, and to devote his life to the execution of that which is right in the eyes of Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch
to praise You, and to glorify You;
and to offer praise and thanks to Your Name.
We are fortunate! How good is our portion!
that we rise early and stay late
The following three lines are to be said silently
now that the world has been created.
and You will exist in the World-to-Come.
and sanctify Your Name in Your world.
and You will uplift our power.
In truth, You are First,59We refer to Hashem as “First” to preclude the notion that anything existed before Him, but not to assert that He has a beginning.—Kuzari
and You are Last.60Similarly, “Last” is used only to repudiate the idea that there is an end to His existence, not to fix a term for Him.—Kuzari
And besides You there is no God.
Gather those who hope in You
from the four corners of the earth.
Let all mankind recognize and know
that You alone are the God61Elohim is a descriptive term which signifies Hashem as ruler or judge.—Kuzari
over all the kingdoms of the earth.
the sea, and all that is in them.
Who is there among all Your handiwork,
among the heavenly or earthly creatures,
that can say to You, “What are You doing?”
for the sake of Your great Name
which is called upon us62The Jewish people are called “Hashem’s People” and the name ישר-אל—officers of Hashem “Yisrael,” by which they are called, includes Hashem’s Name.
and fulfill for us, Adonoy, our God
“‘At that time, I will bring you in
and at that time, I will gather you:
among all the peoples of the earth,
when I bring back your captivity
before your eyes,’ said Adonoy.”63Zephaniah 3:20.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 9_Korbanos (Sacri: The Talmud (Maseches Menachos 110a) states: Rabbi Yitzchak asked, “Why does it say (Vayikra 6:18; 7:1) This is the law of the sin-offering, this is the law of the guilt-offering? To teach us that when one studies the law of the sin-offering, it is considered as though he had actually brought it on the Altar, and when one studies the law of the guilt-offering, it is as though he actually brought it on the Altar.”
Rather than merely recite the following portions, study them and attempt to learn about the laws and significance of the various sacrifices.
Shemos 30:17-21
And Adonoy spoke to Moshe to say:
Make a copper laver
and a copper base, for washing;
and place it
between the Tent of Meeting and the Altar,
and put water in it.
Aharon and his sons will wash from it,
their hands and their feet.64His right hand was held above his right foot, the left hand above the left foot and all were washed simultaneously. Maseches Zevachim 59
Upon entering the Tent of Meeting
they will wash with water that they not die,
or whenever they approach the Altar
to serve, to burn a fire-offering to Adonoy.
They will wash their hands and feet
that they not die;
and this is for them a perpetual statute
for him [Aharon], and his descendants
for all their generations.

The following Scripture section describes the removal of the ashes which had accumulated on the Altar from the daily burnt-offering of the previous afternoon. This removal was performed prior to the daily morning burnt-offering. The passage below also describes the ritual of maintaining the wood pyres which were always burning on the Altar.
Vayikra 6:1
And Adonoy spoke to Moshe to say:
Command Aharon and his sons to say,
this is the law of the burnt-offering.
This is the burnt-offering
[which must remain] on its pyre,
upon the Altar all night,
until morning,
and the fire of the Altar
will be kept burning on it.
The Kohein will don his linen garment,
and linen breeches upon his flesh,
and he will remove the ashes
when the fire consumes
the burnt-offering on the Altar;
and he will place it beside the Altar.
He will remove his garments
and don other garments,
and carry the ashes
outside the camp
to an undefiled place.
The fire upon the altar will be kept burning,
it may not be extinguished.
And the Kohein will burn wood on it
every morning,
and arrange on it the burnt-offering,
and burn on it the fats of the peace-offerings.
A constant fire
will be kept burning on the Altar,
it may not be extinguished.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 10_Korban Tamid (: The Tamid-offerings, two daily offerings of one lamb each, were offered once in the morning and once in the afternoon. The former was the first public-offering brought on the Altar each day. And the latter terminated the day’s offerings. These animals were purchased from the annual half-shekel gifts of the people and were offered on behalf of the entire Jewish People. Before reading this passage we offer a brief prayer.
Adonoy, our God and God of our fathers,
to forgive us all our sins,

These representatives were rotated each week.

for a pleasing aroma, a fire-offering to Adonoy.
a fourth of a hin for the one lamb;

a drink-offering of strong wine to Adonoy.
you will offer in the afternoon;
as the meal-offering of the morning
[together] with its libation, you shall offer
a fire-offering of pleasing aroma to Adonoy.
on the north side of the Altar,
and Aharon’s sons, the Kohanim, will sprinkle
its blood all around the Altar.
Adonoy, our God and God of our fathers,

Adonoy, our God, and God of our fathers,

as if we had offered the Daily offering
and stood in attendance at its service,

two male yearling lambs without blemish;

in addition to the daily burnt-offering

The following sequence of Mish-nayos and the selection from Sifra “Rabbi Yishmael Says,” were inserted after the Scriptural selections dealing with daily- offerings in order to give every Jew the opportunity to study/ recite daily, the minimum of selections from Scripture, Mishnah, and Talmud. Even though Sifra is not actually a Talmudic tractate, it is a Tanaitic expansion of Mishnah. (See Shulchan Aruch, Orach Chaim 50:1).

text.6_The Morning Prayers, 12_Kaddish d'Raba: Kaddish is not the name generally given to this prayer in the Talmud. It is referred to there as “May His great Name...”, because the congregational response beginning with these words is the heart of this prayer. Only in one minor tractate, (Maseches Soferim 16, 19, and 21) is it referred to as Kaddish.

Composed primarily in Aramaic, the language spoken and understood by most Jews in the Second Temple period (See Tosafos to Maseches Berachos 3a), nevertheless, several Hebrew phrases, which were familiar even to the unschooled, were also incorporated in the prayer.

This particular form of Kaddish d’Rabanan, is so named because of the insertion of the paragraph which begins with the words “Upon Yisrael and upon our Sages, etc.” This Kaddish is recited following the study of Talmud or Midrash and invokes God’s blessings on the Sages of Jewry, the transmitters of the Oral Torah.

Exalted and sanctified129These opening words refer to the fulfillment of Hashem’s prophecy, through Yechezkel (38:23) “And I will thus exalt Myself and sanctify Myself; and I will be known in the eyes of the many nations, and they will know that I am Adonoy.”—Levush, Siddur HaGra
(One should be very careful to emphasize the letter gimel (ג) when saying the word “yisgadal (יִתְגַּדַּל),” in order that it not be heard as “Yiskadal (יִתְקַּדַל),” from the word קְדָל which means neck.—Mishnah Berurah 56:2 be His great Name
in the world which He created
according to His will;
and may He rule His Kingdom130May His sovereignty be revealed.
in your lifetime and in your days,
and in the lifetime
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future131We pray that the redemption will come speedily and that the process of the redemption itself will not be prolonged.—Siddur HaGra —
and say Amein.
May His great Name be blessed
forever and for all eternity.132This phrase, the heart of the Kaddish, is found almost verbatim in Daniel 2:20.
Blessed and praised,
glorified, and exalted and uplifted,
honored and elevated and extolled133The ten expressions of praise in the Kaddish refer to the ten utterances by which Hashem created the world. (See Maseches Avos 5:1.)
be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
far above
all the blessings and hymns,134May Hashem be praised and exalted far beyond all the blessings, hymns and praises that are uttered.—Mishnah Berurah in the name of the Vilna Gaon 56:14.
praises and consolations135Consolations are uttered because Hashem is in mourning over the destruction of the Holy Temple and the exile of His people.
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.
Upon Yisrael, and upon our Sages,
and upon their disciples,
and upon all the disciples of their disciples,
and upon all those who engage in Torah study
in this land
and in every land.
May there be unto them and unto you
abundant peace, favor, kindness,
compassion, long life,
ample sustenance and redemption
from their Father
Who is in heaven and on earth,
—and say Amein.
May there be abundant peace from heaven
and a good life
for us and for all Yisrael,
—and say Amein.
He Who makes the peace
in His high heavens
may He, in His mercy, make peace
for us and for all Yisrael,
—and say Amein.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 0: Psalm 30, once used to inaugurate the Holy Temple, is used today to inaugurate our daily prayers, for the synagogue is a “Holy Temple in miniature” and our prayers take the place of the sacrifices. It is both a prayer for success and a declaration of thanksgiving.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 2: a song for the inauguration of the Temple,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 3: by Dovid.1Since it was Shlomo who built the Temple, why is its inauguration attributed to Dovid? Rashi explains: Dovid composed the song which would be sung at the inauguration later, in Shlomo’s days.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 5: for You have upheld me,2Radak writes that the Hebrew word דִלִיתָנִי is an expression used to describe either a downtrodden or an uplifted state. The downtrodden state of the Jewish people is actually part of their uplifting says the Sfas Emes, as it is said, “when I was brought low, He delivered me” (Tehillim 116:6). “My downtrodden state was the cause of my salvation,” proclaims Dovid, just as when one lowers a bucket (דְלִי) into a well in order to bring up the water.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 6: and not let my foes rejoice over me.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 8: I cried out to You, and You healed me.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 1: my soul from the lower world.
lest I descend to the Pit.
Sing to Adonoy, [you,] His pious ones,

and give thanks to His Holy Name.3The literal translation of זֵכֶר קָדְשׁו is His ‘holy remembrance,’ but it refers to His Name; for the titles we bestow upon Him are our means of remembering Him.—Radak
For His anger lasts only a moment,4A moment is a measure of time. Hashem’s anger is limited to time (be it long or short) but Hashem’s favor is unlimited.—Sfas Emes
but there is [long] life, in His conciliation.
In the evening, one retires weeping,
but in the morning there is [a cry of] joy!
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 3: In my going down to destruction?
Hear [me] Adonoy, and be gracious to me,
Adonoy, be a help to me.
You have turned my mourning into dancing,

In order that my soul5The literal translation of כָבוד is glory. Rabbi Yerucham Levovitz explained that the soul is called כָבוד because its only function is to give glory to Hashem. might sing to You
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 13_Mizmor Shir, 4: Adonoy, my God, forever will I thank You.

in the world which He created
and may He rule His Kingdom
in your lifetime and in your days,
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future—

be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.

for us and for all Yisrael,
He Who makes the peace in His high heavens
for us and or all Yisrael,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 15_Pesukei Dezimr: The following sequence of prayers until Yishtabach (p. 94) is called Pesukei Dezimrah (verses of praise). These selected Scriptural passages were arranged by the Gaonim of the ninth century, in fulfillment of the Talmudic statement (Maseches Berachos 32a), “A person should always praise God first and make his requests [offer his prayers] afterwards.” Beginning with Baruch She’amar (p. 80), it is forbidden to interrupt your prayer with conversation until after the Shemoneh Esreh.

You are permitted to answer Amein, respond to Barechu, Kaddish and to say Kedushah even though you have passed Baruch She’amar. You are also permitted to say Modim d’Rabbonon and the first verse of the Shema together with the congregation.

If you are concerned that the saying of Kerias Shema will not be within the proper time should you follow the regular order of prayers, you are permitted to recite the entire Kerias Shema during the Pesukei Dezimrah.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 16_Baruch She'ama: This blessing introduces the Pesukei Dezimrah. It was mentioned by Rabbi Yitzchak Alfasi (Rif) over 800 years ago in his commentary to Maseches Berachos 32. The Taz (Orach Chaim 51:1) states that this prayer was instituted by the “Men of the Great Assembly.” The blessing contains eighty-seven words suggesting the numerical value of פָּז poz, refined gold.
Blessed is He Who spoke,
and the world came into being,
blessed is He;
blessed is He Who maintains the creation;
blessed is He Who says and does;6Hashem’s saying and doing are synonymous and simultaneous as it is said, “By the word of Hashem the heavens were made” (Tehillim 33:6).—Etz Yosef

blessed is He Who decrees and fulfills;7“Says and does” refers to those things that are not lasting and must be renewed whereas, “He decrees and fulfills,” refers to those things that have קִיוּם, and last forever.—Tzelosa d’Avraham
blessed is He Who has compassion
on the earth;
blessed is He Who has compassion

on the creatures;8Not only is Hashem’s compassionate providence concerned with the earth and enduring things, but His compassion and providence extend even to those creatures which are destined to perish.—Avudraham
blessed is He Who rewards well
those who fear Him,
blessed is He Who lives forever
and exists eternally;
blessed is He Who redeems and saves9Hashem redeems those who are in captivity and saves others from being taken in captivity.
blessed is His Name.
Blessed are You, Adonoy,
our God, King of the Universe,
the Almighty, the merciful Father,
Who is verbally extolled by His people,
praised and glorified
by the tongue of His pious ones,
and His servants,
and through the songs of Dovid Your servant,
we will extoll You, Adonoy our God,
with praises and psalms;
we will exalt, praise, and glorify You;
we will mention Your Name,
and proclaim You
our King, our God.
Unique One, Life of the worlds, King,
praised and glorified forever
is His great Name.
Blessed are You, Adonoy,
King, Who is extolled with praises.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 0_Paragr: The first 28 verses of this section are taken from 1 Chronicles 16:8-36, and the first 15 are almost identical with the first fifteen verses of Psalms 105. These prayers are mentioned in Maseches Soferim.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 1_Paragr: Give thanks to Adonoy, proclaim His Name;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 2_Paragr: make His deeds10Make His Divine attributes (mercy, kindness, etc.) known to the world.—Siach Yitzchak known among the nations.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 3_Paragr: Sing to Him, compose songs to Him,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 5_Paragr: Take pride11The Jew should be proud at being found worthy to utter Hashem’s Name.—Siddur HaGra in [uttering] His Holy Name,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 7_Paragr: of those who seek12Seeking Hashem is an end in itself and provides joy to those who earnestly seek Him.—Siach Yitzchak Adonoy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 8_Paragr: Search for Adonoy and His might,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 10_Parag: Remember the wonders He has performed,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 11_Parag: His miracles,13His “miracles” were witnessed by Jew and Egyptian alike in Egypt. His “laws” are the Torah He gave us at Mt. Sinai.—Iyun Tefillah and the laws from His mouth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 12_Parag: [You,] the seed of Yisrael14The entire section—the previous verses as well as the following verses—are addressed to the Jewish People, who are the seed of Yisrael, the chosen of Hashem, who are asked to remember His wonders, miracles and laws.—Tzelosa d’Avraham His servant,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 13_Parag: children of Yaakov, His chosen ones.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 15_Parag: the entire earth is governed by His laws.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 19_Parag: which He made as a treaty with Avraham,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 20_Parag: and [which was] His oath to Yitzchak.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 21_Parag: He established it for Yaakov as a statute,
