text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 22_Parag: for Yisrael as an everlasting covenant.15This verse in following the preceding verse indicates that the original covenant which Hashem made with Avraham was later confirmed to Yitzchak in an oath and then established for Yaakov as a statute. After Yaakov was given the name Yisrael, it became an everlasting covenant.—Tzelosa d’Avraham
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 24_Parag: “To you I will give the Land of Canaan,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 26_Parag: When you were only few in number—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 27_Parag: very few, and strangers in it.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 28_Parag: They wandered from nation to nation,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 29_Parag: and from one kingdom to another people.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 30_Parag: He permitted no one to oppress them,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 31_Parag: and admonished kings16Both Pharaoh and Avimelech were admonished for Avraham’s sake (Bereishis 13:17; 20:3,7). for their sake.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 32_Parag: “Do not touch My anointed ones,17The Hebrew word מְשִׁיחָי can also be translated as “My great ones” and as such refers to the Patriarchs. “My prophets” refers to the Matriarchs, who were known to be prophets. Both were afforded extraordinary Divine protection.—Etz Yosef
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 33_Parag: and do not harm My prophets.”
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 34_Parag: Sing to Adonoy all the earth,18Siach Yitzchak maintains that this verse directs Jewry to sing to Hashem in all the lands in which they are dispersed during their exile. Tzelosa d’Avraham understands the verse to direct all the nations of the earth to sing to Hashem.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 35_Parag: proclaim His deliverance from day to day.19a) We are to proclaim our deliverance by Hashem every day; b) We are to proclaim that our deliverance by Hashem is a daily experience.—Tzelosa d’Avraham
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 36_Parag: Recount His glory among the nations,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 37_Parag: His wonders among all the peoples.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 38_Parag: For Adonoy is great and most extolled;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 39_Parag: Awesome is He above all gods.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 40_Parag: For all the gods of the peoples are idols,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 42_Parag: Beauty and splendor are before Him,20The word הוד (beauty) indicates that which is itself beautiful, while הָדָר (splendor) is the reflection of beauty. For example: the sun’s light is “beauty” itself while the moon’s light is splendor—a reflection of the sun. (This definition applies only to the Hebrew terms.)—Siddur HaGra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 43_Parag: strength and joy are in His presence.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 44_Parag: Give to Adonoy families of peoples—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 45_Parag: give to Adonoy glory and might.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 46_Parag: Give to Adonoy the glory due His Name,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 47_Parag: bring an offering and come before Him,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 49_Parag: in the splendor of holiness.21Etz Yosef understands this as the “holy splendor” of Hashem’s Sanctuary. Tzelosa d’Avraham sees it as the splendor and joy of worship before Hashem, as contrasted with secular, frivolous manifestations of beauty and splendor.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 50_Parag: Tremble before Him all [peoples of] the earth,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 51_Parag: for He established the inhabited world
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 52_Parag: so that it cannot be moved.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 54_Parag: the earth will exult,22Simcha (rejoicing) describes one’s feelings at a new experience of happiness, whereas gila (exultation) describes the feeling one experiences over an ongoing situation of joy. Since there is nothing new on the earth וְאֵין כָּל־חָדָשׁ תַּחַת הַשָּׁמֶשׁ (Koheles 1:9), it is said the earth will exult (gila); but the heavens will rejoice (simcha) because there is חִידוּשׁ in the heavens.—Gaon of Vilna
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 55_Parag: and they will proclaim among the nations:
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 57_Parag: The sea and its fullness will roar;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 58_Parag: the field and all that is in it will jubilate.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 59_Parag: Then the trees of the forest will sing with joy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 61_Parag: when He comes to judge the earth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 62_Parag: Give thanks to Adonoy, for He is good,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 64_Parag: And say, “Deliver us, God of our deliverance;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 65_Parag: gather us and save us from the nations,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 66_Parag: to give thanks to Your Holy Name,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 67_Parag: to be extolled in Your praise.”23The fact that we are privileged to sing Your praises and cling to You will make us praiseworthy.—Etz Yosef
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 68_Parag: Blessed is Adonoy, the God of Yisrael
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 74_Parag: at His footstool.24The Holy Temple.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 75_Parag: Holy is He!25Or Holy is it—i.e., the Temple.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 78_Parag: at His holy mountain,26Mount Moriah upon which the Holy Temple was built is holy itself even when the Temple is destroyed. The previous verse refers to the time of the Temple, the second verse refers to the period of its destruction.—Etz Yosef
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 79_Parag: for Adonoy our God is holy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 81_Parag: atones iniquity and does not destroy;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 83_Parag: and does not arouse all His rage.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 85_Parag: withhold not Your mercy from me;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 86_Parag: may Your kindness and Your truth27חֶסֶד (kindness) is the good Hashem bestows without a promise, whereas אֱמֶת (truth) is the fulfillment of His promise.—Siach Yitzchak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 91_Parag: they are from the beginning of the world.28Hashem’s mercies to mankind started from the very day that Adam was created. Hashem created the world in order to fill it with kindness as it is said: “A world of kindness was built” (Tehillim 89:3).—Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 92_Parag: Give might to God,29Attribute your victories to Hashem’s might rather than to your own.—Siach Yitzchak. Rashbam and others hold that since Hashem’s actions are a reflection of Yisrael’s deeds, the latter are, in a sense, the source of His might. Thus when Yisrael follows the wishes of Hashem, they give might to Him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 94_Parag: and His might is in the clouds.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 96_Parag: from Your Sanctuaries,30There is a spiritual Temple in the heavens which corresponds to the Temple on earth.—Radak. The Talmud (Maseches Zevachim 115b) notes that the word מִמִּקְדָּשֶׁיךָ may also be read מִמְקוּדָשֶׁיךָ, from Your holy people, indicating that Hashem is especially demanding of the most adherent to the Torah. When this occurs, the world is filled with awe and fear of Hashem.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 98_Parag: He grants might and power to the people;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 101_Para: Almighty of vengeance, reveal Yourself.31These two verses (94:1-2) are an appeal to Hashem during a time fraught with the sufferings of exile, when it seems as if Hashem has forsaken His people. He is urged to reveal Himself as the Mighty champion of justice—S.R. Hirsch
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 103_Para: Repay the arrogant their just reward.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 104_Para: Deliverance is Adonoy’s.32Only Hashem knows what is true deliverance for a person. Prayer is not always answered, because Hashem in His infinite wisdom knows that granting the request is not always for our benefit. We must therefore bless and offer thanks to Hashem regardless of whether our petition has been granted.—Siach Yitzchak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 105_Para: Upon Your people is Your blessing. Selah.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 106_Para: Adonoy of Hosts is with us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 107_Para: a stronghold for us is the God of Yaakov. Selah.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 109_Para: Fortunate is the man who trusts in You.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 111_Para: The King will answer us on the day we call.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 114_Para: tend them and uplift them forever.33Radak understands Dovid to be asking Hashem to raise the People of Yisrael above their enemies. Ibn Ezra says that Hashem is being asked to act like a shepherd who brings his flock to high ground to save them from beasts of prey.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 116_Para: our help and our shield is He.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 117_Para: For in Him our hearts will rejoice,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 118_Para: for in His Holy Name we trusted.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 119_Para: May Your kindness, Adonoy, be upon us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 120_Para: as we have waited for You.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 122_Para: and grant34We hope to earn redemption through our deeds, but if we are found wanting, then “show us Your kindness”—overlook our deficiencies and “grant” us salvation.—Radak us Your deliverance.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 124_Para: and redeem us for the sake of Your kindness.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 128_Para: open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.35Request all that you desire and I will fulfill every request.—Ibn Ezra. The Yerushalayim Talmud (Maseches Taanis 3:6) indicates that the more one requests Hashem’s providence—the “wider he opens his mouth”—the more he shows his belief in Hashem’s ability to provide all of man’s needs.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 129_Para: Fortunate is the people whose lot is thus,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 131_Para: for whom Adonoy is their God.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 132_Para: In Your loving kindness I trust,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 133_Para: My heart will exult in Your deliverance;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 135_Para: for He dealt kindly with me.36The foremost level of man’s trust in Hashem is manifested in three situations: a)when he is confronted with trouble, b)when he seeks help, and c)after he has been helped. The Psalmist says: In my time of trouble, I trust in Your kindliness; I seek only Your help, for my heart exults in Your salvation; and I will sing to You afterwards for You have dealt kindly with me.—Siddur HaGra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 136_Para: In this psalm, (19) Dovid sings the praises of the Torah. The Kuzari notes that even though the skies “proclaim God’s glory” and the Psalmist describes the sun so glowingly, Dovid nevertheless concludes that in comparison to the Torah they are insignificant.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 139_Para: The skies recount the glory of the Almighty,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 141_Para: is related by the firmament.37שָׁמַיִם, skies, refers to the heavenly regions beyond earth’s atmosphere, where the stars and planets orbit. רָקִיעַ, firmament, refers to the earth’s atmosphere where clouds form, and precipitation takes place. The verb לְסַפֵּר means to recount something which occurred in the past. Thus the stars and planets in the שָׁמַיִם recount the fact that long ago Hashem created a glorious universe. The רָקִיעַ, on the other hand, relates that Hashem’s handiwork is evidenced in the constant formation of clouds and in the precipitation of rain. The firmament enables man to recognize the constant renewal of Hashem’s providence.—Malbim
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 142_Para: Day to day makes speech flow,38Daily renewal of the activities of creation, beginning with sunrise, stir mankind to proclaim Hashem’s praises.—Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 143_Para: and night to night expresses wisdom.39Night after night the sun sets beneath the horizon only to rise and set again the following day. This unchanging pattern is evidence of the Divine wisdom implanted in Hashem’s creation.—Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 144_Para: There is no speech, and there are no words;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 145_Para: their voice is never heard.40Though the heavens have no means of verbal communication, the soul of man, with its sensitivity and perception, can understand their message clearly.—Ibn Ezra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 146_Para: Throughout the earth, their line extends,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 147_Para: and to the edge of the inhabited world
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 149_Para: He has set a tent in their midst for the sun.41Hashem provided the sun a permanent residence in the heavens. Dovid describes this point to which the sun returns daily as its ‘tent’—its residence in the sky.—Metsudas Yehoshua
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 150_Para: And it [the sun] is like a groom
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 151_Para: departing his bridal chamber,42When the groom steps out of the bridal chamber, everyone rushes to greet him with great joy. Analogously, when the sun rises each day, all of creation rejoices.—Radak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 152_Para: happy as a warrior to run on course.43A warrior is happy for the opportunity to go into battle because he has confidence in his skill and strength. Similarly, the sun rejoices knowing it will serve its Creator’s goals by running its course.—Metsudas Dovid.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 153_Para: From one end of the skies is its rising
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 154_Para: and its circuit is to their [other] end;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 155_Para: there is no escaping its heat.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 156_Para: The Torah of Adonoy, is perfect,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 158_Para: the testimony of Adonoy, is trustworthy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 160_Para: The precepts of Adonoy, are upright,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 162_Para: the commandment of Adonoy, is lucid,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 163_Para: enlightening the eyes.44Every command of Hashem is flawless, lighting the way for those who walk in His way. Those who ignore His commands stumble in darkness.—Radak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 164_Para: The fear of Adonoy, is pure,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 166_Para: the judgments of Adonoy, are true,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 167_Para: they are righteous in unison.45They are all in total harmony. There is no contradiction between them.—Ibn Ezra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 169_Para: even more than quantities of fine gold;46פָּז is the purest form of refined gold.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 172_Para: Even Your servant is careful of them,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 173_Para: since they guard47Because the Divine reward is contingent on fulfilling Hashem’s commands, they are ‘guardians’ of that reward.—Metsudas Yehoshua great reward.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 178_Para: let them not rule me,48Dovid’s request is paraphrased in the concluding blessing of the בִּרְכוֹת הַשַּׁחַר, where we say וְאַל יִשְׁלֹט בָּנוּ יֵצֶר הָרַע, “Let us not be ruled by the Evil Inclination.” Dovid knows full well that Hashem does not interfere with man’s free choise; he only asks for Divine help to keep him from becoming a prisoner of evil.—Gaon of Vilna
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 180_Para: and will be cleansed of gross transgression.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 181_Para: May the words of my mouth be acceptable
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 182_Para: and the thoughts of my heart — before You
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 183_Para: Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 184_Para: This psalm (34) is based entirely on an event that took place in Dovid’s personal life as related in 1 Shmuel 21:11-16. Forced to flee from Saul, he took refuge among the Philistines, where he was recognized as the slayer of Goliath. In order to escape death at the hands of his foes, Dovid pretended to be an imbecile, and was sent away unharmed by King Avimelech.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 190_Para: I will bless Adonoy at all times
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 191_Para: constantly is His praise in my mouth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 192_Para: In Adonoy does my soul take pride,49Dovid is proud that he is worthy of uttering Hashem’s Name.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 193_Para: the humble will hear [this] and rejoice.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 194_Para: Declare the greatness of Adonoy with me,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 195_Para: and let us exalt His Name together.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 196_Para: I sought Adonoy and He responded to me;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 197_Para: and from all my fears He saved me.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 198_Para: [Those who] look to Him are enlightened
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 201_Para: This poor man50Dovid describes himself as a helpless indigent waiting for Hashem’s compassion.—Radak called and Adonoy heard;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 202_Para: and from all his troubles, He delivered him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 206_Para: Taste and see that Adonoy is good;51Seporno says that taste refers to the senses whereas “see” refers to the intellect.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 212_Para: Young lions feel want and hunger,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 214_Para: will not lack any good thing.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 216_Para: fear of Adonoy will I teach you.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 217_Para: Who is the man who desires life,52Dovid does not say הֶחָפֵץ בַּחַיִּים ‘he who takes pleasure in life’ but הֶחָפֵץ חַיִּים, ‘he who desires life,’ whose only goal is life; that is, he desires to attain such a level of existence as can truly be called life.—S.R. Hirsch
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 218_Para: and loves days that he may see good?
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 220_Para: and your lips from speaking deceitfully.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 221_Para: Turn from evil and do good,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 223_Para: The eyes of Adonoy are toward the righteous,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 224_Para: and His ears [are open] to their cry.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 225_Para: The face53The expression פְּנֵי ה', Face of Hashem, describes Divine anger. See Vayikra 20:5, וְשַׂמְתִּי אֲנִי אֶת פָּנַי בָּאִישׁ הַהוּא, “And I will set My Face against that man.” of Adonoy is set against evildoers
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 226_Para: to excise from earth, their memory.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 227_Para: They54They refers to the righteous ones (Rashi) and to the repentant sinners (Ibn Ezra). cry out and Adonoy hears
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 228_Para: and from all their troubles, He saves them.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 229_Para: Adonoy is close to the broken-hearted
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 230_Para: and those crushed in spirit, He delivers.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 231_Para: Many evils befall a righteous man,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 232_Para: and from all of them, Adonoy saves him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 234_Para: not one of them is broken.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 235_Para: The cause of death of the wicked is evil;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 236_Para: and the haters of the righteous are doomed.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 237_Para: Adonoy liberates the soul of His servants,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 240_Para: According to our Sages, Psalms 90 through 101, were said by Moshe. According to Radak, Dovid actually found this psalm in its written form and knowing it to be the prayer of Moshe, included it in his book of psalms. It speaks of the frailty of man and the brevity of his life and asks for God’s compassion and favor despite his wrongdoings.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 241_Para: A prayer of Moshe, the man of God:
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 243_Para: a dwelling[-place] have You been for us
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 246_Para: and You brought forth the earth
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 248_Para: from world to world55From before this world to the next world You are Almighty.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 251_Para: until the crushing point56You permit the sinner to return in penitence even till the very last moment of his life.—Iyun Tefiloh
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 253_Para: “Return, children of man!”57You constantly call the sinner to return, reminding him of the brevity of his life.—Iyun Tefiloh
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 254_Para: For a thousand years are in Your eyes
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 255_Para: like the yesterday that has just passed,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 257_Para: The stream of their life is [but] slumber,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 259_Para: they are as grass, freshly grown.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 262_Para: by evening it is cut off and shriveled.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 263_Para: So are we consumed by Your anger
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 264_Para: and by Your rage are we terrified.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 265_Para: You have set our iniquities before You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 266_Para: the sins of our youth58Others translate ‘our hidden sins [are exposed]’ see Metsudas Dovid
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 267_Para: before the light of Your countenance.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 272_Para: The days of our years in them59‘In them’ refers to the iniquities and the youth mentioned in the two preceding verses. —Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 275_Para: and their pride is frustration and falsehood;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 276_Para: for, cut off quickly, we fly away.60Not only is the span of our lives brief, but our few allotted years fly by swiftly.—Iyun Tefiloh
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 279_Para: And like the fear of You so is Your wrath.61Just as Hashem is feared, so too is His wrath harsh when He punishes sinners.—Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 280_Para: To count our days, teach us
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 281_Para: and we will acquire a heart of wisdom.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 282_Para: Turn Adonoy—how long?62Turn away from Your wrath! How much longer will You make us suffer?—Targum
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 283_Para: And change Your mind about Your servants.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 284_Para: Satisfy us in the morning63The Sages say that the morning refers to the time of our redemption after the long, black nights of exile.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 286_Para: and we will sing and rejoice
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 287_Para: throughout our days.64If You show us kindliness in the morning of our youth, showing us the way of righteousness; we will rejoice and sing in our old age.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 288_Para: Make us rejoice65Make us rejoice in the era of the Moshiach for as long as we suffered in exile.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 289_Para: like the days You afflicted us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 291_Para: Let be revealed to Your servants,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 293_Para: and Your splendor be upon their children.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 294_Para: May the pleasantness of my Master our God
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 295_Para: be upon us,66In this closing verse, Moshe prays that the Divine Presence rest on the Jewish nation exclusively.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 296_Para: and the work of our hands established for us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 297_Para: and the work of our hands—establish it.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 298_Para: This Psalm, (91) composed by Moshe on the day the Tabernacle was completed, is a source of inspiration to all who seek the Almighty as their refuge and fortress.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 300_Para: in the shelter of the Supreme One,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 301_Para: under the protection of Shadai he will abide.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 303_Para: [He is] my refuge and my stronghold,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 304_Para: my God in Whom I trust.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 305_Para: For He will save you from the snare-trap,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 307_Para: With His wings He will cover you
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 308_Para: and beneath His wings, you will find refuge;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 309_Para: His truth is a shield, a full shield.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 310_Para: You will not fear the terror of night,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 311_Para: nor the arrow that flies by day.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 312_Para: The pestilence that prowls in darkness,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 313_Para: nor the deadly plague that ravages at noon.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 314_Para: A thousand will fall at your [left] side,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 315_Para: and ten thousand at your [right] side
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 316_Para: but it67‘It’ refers to ‘arrow,’ pestilence,’ and ‘plague’ mentioned in the preceding two verse. shall not come near you.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 317_Para: Only68You will only see the destruction but you will not be harmed by it. with your eyes will you behold
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 318_Para: and see the punishment of the wicked.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 324_Para: and no plague shall come near your tent.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 326_Para: He will command on your behalf—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 327_Para: to guard you in all your ways.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 328_Para: They will carry you upon their hands,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 329_Para: lest you hurt your foot on a rock.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 330_Para: You will tread upon lion and snake,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 331_Para: you will trample young lion and serpent.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 332_Para: Because he clings to Me with desire,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 336_Para: When he calls upon Me, I will answer him;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 337_Para: I am with him in distress,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 338_Para: I will free him and honor him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 339_Para: I will satiate him with longevity,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 340_Para: and will let him see My deliverance.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 341_Para: I will satiate him with longevity,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 342_Para: and will let him see My deliverance.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 343_Para: In this psalm, (135) Dovid praises God for choosing the people of Israel as His treasured people. He also speaks of those who will ultimately be worthy of serving Him, in the rebuilt House of God, in the Messianic era.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 347_Para: [You] who stand in the House of Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 348_Para: in the courtyards of the House of our God.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 349_Para: Praise God, for Adonoy is good,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 350_Para: sing to His Name which is pleasant.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 351_Para: For God chose Yaakov to be His,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 355_Para: our Master [is greater] than all gods.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 356_Para: All that was desired by Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 357_Para: He has done in heaven and on earth,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 358_Para: in the seas and all the depths.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 360_Para: from the ends of the earth;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 361_Para: lightning for the rain He makes;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 362_Para: He brings forth winds from His vaults.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 363_Para: He struck down the firstborn of Mitzrayim
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 367_Para: upon Pharaoh and upon all his servants.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 371_Para: and Og, King of the Bashan,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 372_Para: and all the kingdoms of Canaan.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 373_Para: And He gave their lands as an inheritance,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 374_Para: an inheritance to Yisrael, His people.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 376_Para: Adonoy is Your mention for generations.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 377_Para: For Adonoy judges His people,69According to Seporno, the verse is translated, ‘When Adonoy judges on behalf of His people,’ referring to the judgement of all who oppressed the Jewish people.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 378_Para: and upon His servants will He relent.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 379_Para: The idols70עֲצַבֵּי is related to עֶצֶב which means ‘sadness’ or ‘grief.’ Idols bring only grief to those who depend on them.—Radak of the nations,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 382_Para: They have a mouth but do not speak;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 383_Para: they have eyes but do not see.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 384_Para: They have ears but do not listen;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 385_Para: nor is there any breath in their mouth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 386_Para: Like them let their makers be—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 388_Para: House of Yisrael, bless Adonoy!71The entire house of Yisrael is urged to bless Hashem Who set us apart from the other nations and made us His people. Yisrael is told to bless Hashem for its own unique position and manner of serving Him.— Ibn Ezra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 391_Para: [You] who fear Adonoy,72This refers to those among the nations who converted to Judaism because of their fear and recognition of Hashem. bless Adonoy!
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 395_Para: The Talmud (Pesachim 118a) calls this psalm (136) הַלֵל הַגָדוֹל, the great praise, because it describes how God, enthroned on high, sustains every living creature. The first twenty-four verses call on us to thank God, the Master of the Universe, Who created it, redeemed us from Mitzrayim, caused us to inherit the lands of Sichon and Og, and delivered us from our enemies. The twenty-fifth verse, נוֹתֵן לֶחֶם לְכָל בָּשָׂר, He gives food to all flesh, is viewed as the climax of the entire psalm. Feeding every creature, day in and day out, is the greatest manifestation of God’s provident kindliness. Though He rules in supreme splendor, God is close to the needs of every creature.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 397_Para: for His kindliness endures forever.73This refrain is repeated in all twenty-six verses of the Psalm. We thereby declare that each act of kindliness for which we thank Hashem is not of a temporary nature, lasting merely a day or a year. The effect of His kindliness endures forever, and we continually reap the benefits of every act of Divine kindliness.—Sfas Emes
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 402_Para: He Who does great wonders, alone,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 407_Para: He Who spreads the earth over the waters,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 409_Para: He Who makes the great luminaries,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 411_Para: The sun to rule by day,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 419_Para: He brought Yisrael out of their midst,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 421_Para: With a strong hand and outstretched arm,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 423_Para: He Who parted the Sea of Reeds into parts,74The sea was divided into twelve parts, so that each tribe crossed on its own route.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 425_Para: And He made Yisrael pass through it
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 427_Para: And He threw Pharaoh and his army
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 439_Para: And Og, king of the Bashan,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 441_Para: And gave their land as an inheritance,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 443_Para: An inheritance to Yisrael, His servant,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 445_Para: In our lowliness, He remembered us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 447_Para: And He freed us from our oppressors,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 449_Para: He gives food to all flesh,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 452_Para: for His kindliness endures forever.75The twenty six verses in this psalm symbolize the twenty six generations of man from Creation till the Torah was given. These generations were sustained solely by virtue of Hashem’s kindliness even though they did not have the merit of Torah.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 453_Para: In this psalm, (33) Dovid expresses the joy of the righteous in the Divine Providence of God in every aspect of the world and in the affairs of man. For the righteous see the “laws of nature” only as an external cloak, concealing the true supervision of God. They see through the laws of nature and perceive the Divine order and providence of the Creator.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 455_Para: for the upright, praise is fitting.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 457_Para: with the ten-stringed lyre sing to Him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 460_Para: For upright is the word of Adonoy
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 461_Para: and all His deeds [are done] with faithfulness.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 463_Para: the kindliness of Adonoy fills the earth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 464_Para: By the word of God, the heavens were made,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 465_Para: and by the breath of His mouth,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 469_Para: He places in vaults the deep waters.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 472_Para: all dwellers of the inhabited world.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 473_Para: For He spoke and it became;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 475_Para: Adonoy annuls the counsel of nations,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 476_Para: He disrupts the intention of peoples.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 477_Para: The counsel of Adonoy will stand forever,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 481_Para: for whom Adonoy is their God,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 482_Para: the people He chose as His heritage.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 487_Para: all the inhabitants of the earth.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 488_Para: He forms their hearts all together;76The Talmud (Sanhedrin 37a) states: When a man mints many coins from the same mold, they are all exactly alike, but Hashem formed all of mankind from Adam and no two men look exactly alike. The Sages in Berachos 58a add: just as no two faces are alike, so are no two personalities alike. Thus even though Hashem made them all together, each has his own unique personality.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 490_Para: A king is not saved by a great army;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 491_Para: a mighty man is not rescued
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 498_Para: is on those who fear Him,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 499_Para: on those who wait for His kindliness.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 500_Para: To rescue their soul from death,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 501_Para: and to keep them alive during famine.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 503_Para: our help and our shield is He.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 504_Para: For in Him our heart will rejoice,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 505_Para: for in His Holy Name we trust,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 506_Para: May Your kindliness, Adonoy, be upon us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 507_Para: as we have waited for You.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 508_Para: A Psalm, a song for the Shabbos day.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 509_Para: It is good to thank77Shabbos, more than other days, lends itself to offering praise and thanksgiving to Hashem. When man rests from his physical labor and is relieved of material concerns, his soul is free to pursue the intellectual and spiritual aspects of life. These pursuits lead him to serve Hashem and to praise Him.—Radak Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 510_Para: and sing praise to Your Name, Most High.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 511_Para: To relate Your kindliness in the morning,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 512_Para: and Your faithfulness in the nights.78We will proclaim His kindliness in the morning of redemption. And while yet in the darkness of exile we proclaim our belief in His faithfulness.—Rashi
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 513_Para: Upon a ten-stringed instrument and lute,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 515_Para: For You have given me joy, Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 517_Para: at the work of Your hands79The Shabbos day of rest affords me the opportunity to observe and appreciate the greatness of Your work.—Radak I sing joyously.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 518_Para: How great are Your works, Adonoy;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 519_Para: how infinitely profound are Your thoughts.80Hashem’s ‘works’ are the visible creation, while His ‘thoughts’ are the Divine purpose behind each created thing.—Seporno
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 521_Para: nor does a fool understand this:
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 522_Para: When the wicked bloom like grass,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 524_Para: it is so that they may be destroyed forever.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 525_Para: But You will remain on high forever, Adonoy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 527_Para: For behold, Your enemies shall perish;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 529_Para: You uplifted my horn81Others translate, ‘You have increased my might like that of the wild ram.’ like that of a unicorn;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 530_Para: I am saturated with fresh oil.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 531_Para: My eye has seen [the defeat of]
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 533_Para: of the wicked who rise against me,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 534_Para: my ears have heard [that they are doomed].
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 535_Para: The righteous will blossom like a date palm,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 536_Para: like a cedar82The palm and the cedar both enjoy a long life span and flourish during all seasons. Thus they symbolize the lasting happiness of the righteous in contrast to the short prosperity of the wicked. in Lebanon, he will grow tall.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 537_Para: Planted in the House of Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 538_Para: in the courtyards of our God
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 540_Para: They will still be fruitful in old age;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 541_Para: they will be full of sap and freshness.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 542_Para: To declare that Adonoy is upright;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 544_Para: in Whom there is no injustice.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 546_Para: He has clothed Himself with majesty;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 548_Para: He has girded Himself with strength.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 549_Para: He has firmly established the world
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 550_Para: so that it cannot be moved.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 551_Para: Your throne stands firm from of old,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 554_Para: the rivers have raised their voice,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 555_Para: the rivers raise their raging waves.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 556_Para: More than the sound of many waters,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 557_Para: mightier than the breakers of the sea
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 558_Para: Mighty on high, are You, Adonoy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 17_Hodu, 560_Para: holiness is becoming to Your House,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 0_: This prayer, mentioned in Maseches Sof’rim 17:11 is a collection of 18 verses from Psalms, Chronicles, and Proverbs, in which the Divine Name (הויה) is mentioned 18 times. Great care should be taken to pronounce the “Name” with the utmost concentration, keeping in mind that He is the Supreme Master of all that exists.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 1_: The glory of Adonoy will endure forever;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 2_: Adonoy will rejoice in His works.83Tehillim 104:31.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 3_: The Name of Adonoy will be blessed
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 5_: From the rising of the sun to its setting,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 6_: praised is the Name of Adonoy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 7_: High above all nations is Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 8_: above the heavens is His glory.84Tehillim 113:24.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 9_: Adonoy, Your Name85Hashem’s “Name” is the name spelled Yud-Hey-Vuv-Hey. is forever,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 10: Adonoy, Your Mention86Hashem’s “mention” is the name spelled Alef-Daled-Nun-Yud. In this world Hashem’s Name is only written as Y-H-V-H but is pronounced Adonoy. In the future world, however, Hashem’s Name will be pronounced as it is written. Thus the Psalmist means: “Your Name is eternal, but Your mention is solely from generation to generation.—Siach Yitzchak is for generations.87Tehillim 135:13.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 11: Adonoy has established His throne in heaven,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 12: [but] His dominion rules over all.88Tehillim 103:19.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 13: The heavens will rejoice, the earth will exult,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 14: and they will proclaim among the nations:
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 15: “Adonoy has begun His reign.89Divrei Hayamim I 16:31.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 16: Adonoy is King, Adonoy was King;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 17: Adonoy will be King forever and ever.”
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 18: Adonoy will reign for all eternity
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 19: [when] nations have perished from His earth.90Tehillim 10:16.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 20: Adonoy annuls the counsel of nations,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 21: He disrupts the intention of peoples.91Tehillim 33:10.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 22: Many thoughts are in the heart of man,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 23: but [only] Adonoy’s counsel will endure.92Mishlei 19:21.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 24: The counsel of Adonoy will stand forever,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 27: For He spoke and it came to be;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 28: He commanded and it stood.94Tehillim 33:9.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 30: He desired it for His dwelling place.95Tehillim 132:13.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 31: For God chose Yaakov to be His,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 32: Yisrael for His treasure.96Tehillim 135:4.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 33: For Adonoy will not cast off His people,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 34: and His inheritance, He will not abandon.97Tehillim 94:13.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 36: atones iniquity; and does not destroy.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 38: and does not arouse all His rage.98Tehillim 78:38.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 40: The King will answer us on the day we call.99Tehillim 20:10.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 41: Rav S.R. Hirsch writes that the six concluding chapters of the Book of Psalms are the most important gift of Dovid’s Divinely-inspired hymns. They are an essential component of our daily prayers. Our Sages attach much significance to Psalm 145 in particular, and stated: “Whoever recites ‘A praise by Dovid’ three times a day is assuredly worthy of a share in the World to Come” (Berachos 4b). When recited in prayer, this psalm is always introduced with two verses from other Psalms (84:5 and 144:15). These verses contain the word fortunate three times, an allusion to this psalm being recited three times a day. These verses are so closely identified with Psalm 145 that it is commonly referred to as Ashrei (Fortunate).
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 43: in Your house;100This verse referred to the Kohanim and the Levites who served (dwelt) in the Holy Temple (Your House); it is at all times applicable to scholars and devout men who study and pray in houses of worship and study.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 44: may they continue to praise You, Selah.101Tehillim 84:5
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 45: Fortunate is the people whose lot is thus;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 47: for whom Adonoy is their God.102Tehillim 144:15
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 49: I will exalt You, my God, the King,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 50: and bless Your Name forever and ever.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 51: Every day I will bless You103According to Rav S.R. Hirsch, Dovid here declares, “I will dedicate myself to serve You and to fulfill Your will in loyal obedience,” for in serving Hashem, man causes His Name to be blessed.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 52: and extol Your Name forever and ever.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 53: Adonoy is great and highly extolled,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 57: and Your mighty acts they will declare.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 58: The splendor of Your glorious majesty,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 59: and the words104Not simply נִפְלְאתֶיךָ—a report of Your wonders—but דִבְרֵי נִפְלְאתֶיךָ the “words”—the lessons that Your wonders teach.—S.R. Hirsch of Your wonders I will speak.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 60: Of Your awesome might, they105People in general will speak of Hashem’s wondrous might in punishing the wicked (Sodom, Egypt, etc.) while Dovid will proclaim that Hashem’s greatness is measured more by His kindliness than by His awesomeness.—Siach Yitzchak will speak,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 61: and Your greatness I will recount.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 64: and in Your righteousness joyfully exult.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 65: Adonoy is gracious and merciful,106He is gracious in bestowing reward and merciful in punishment.—Siach Yitzchak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 66: slow to anger and great in kindliness.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 68: His mercy encompasses all His works.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 69: All Your works will thank You, Adonoy,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 70: and Your pious ones will bless You.107Your works which are the cause of your being thanked by sensitive people; similarly, cause your pious ones to bless You.—based on S.R. Hirsch.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 71: Of the honor of Your kingship,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 73: and Your might they will declare.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 74: To reveal to men His mighty acts,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 75: and the glorious splendor of His Kingship.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 76: Your kingship is the kingship for all times,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 77: and Your dominion is in every generation.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 80: The eyes of all look expectantly to You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 82: their food at its proper time.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 84: and satisfy the desire of every living being.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 85: Adonoy is just in all His ways
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 86: and benevolent in all His deeds.108The penalties for transgressions are just, but Hashem is gracious in the actual punishment inflicted on the sinner.—Siddur HaGra
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 87: Adonoy is near to all who call upon Him,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 88: to all who call upon Him in truth.109He is near to all who call upon Him, but His nearness can be perceived only by those who call upon Him in truth, who truly mean to have Hashem enter into their lives.—S.R. Hirsch
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 89: The will of those who fear Him, He fulfills;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 90: He hears their cry and delivers them.110While Hashem hears all who cry unto Him in truth, He answers those who fear Him, who subject their desires to His will.—Siach Yitzchak
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 91: Adonoy watches over all those who love Him,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 92: and will destroy all the wicked.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 93: Praise of Adonoy, my mouth will declare
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 95: His Holy Name forever and ever.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 98: Praise God.111Tehillim 115:18. You should pause between עוֹלָם and הַלְלוּיָהּ. Similarly, in all the Tehillim, the word הַלְלוּיָהּ is not connected to the preceding verse.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 99: This Psalm acclaims God’s loving care as experienced by each Jew in his own life.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 10: I will praise Adonoy with my life;
I will sing to my God as long as I live.
[even] in noble men,112According to the Sages, it is implied that one should not rely even on the merit of his sainted ancestors, the Patriarchs, for deliverance.
in man who has no [power of] deliverance.
he returns to his earth;113Only the four cubits of ground which will receive him one day are his; of all the world they are the one possession which is guaranteed to him.—S.R. Hirsch
on that day his plans come to naught.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 11: when the Almighty of Yaakov is his help,114Yaakov, more than anyone, sensed Hashem’s nearness and protection throughout his difficult life and through all the trials to which he was subjected.—S.R. Hirsch
whose expectation is on Adonoy, his God.
the sea and all that is in them;
He keeps His promises faithfully forever.115He alone has always proven dependable and faithful, for there are no limits to His essence and to His power.—Ibn Ezra, Radak
He performs justice for the oppressed;
He gives bread to the hungry;
Adonoy gives sight to the blind;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 12: and the way of the wicked He thwarts.
your God, Tziyon, throughout all generations.

In this Psalm, Dovid imparts the knowledge to sustain and uphold the Jewish People, during their bitter exile. He tells them of their special and enduring relationship with God and of their role as permanent messengers of the word of God to all mankind.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 13: for it is good to sing to our God;
The builder of Yerushalayim is Adonoy;
the banished ones of Yisrael He will gather.
[He is] the Healer of the broken-hearted
and [also] binds up their wounds.116Others render “their sorrows.” Both translations co-exist! Hashem not only heals their physical pains but also abbreviates their sorrows as well.
He fixes the number of stars;
He calls all of them by names.117Not one of the myriad stars was created accidentally; each has a unique purpose and function.—Siach Yitzchak
Great is our Master and abundant in power;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 14: Adonoy causes the humble to stand firm;
He casts down the wicked to the ground.
Cry out to Adonoy in thanksgiving;

sing to our God with the harp.118Each musical instrument has its unique function. In the times of King Dovid, the harp was used to arouse those who slept. The psalmist may be indicating that the harp arouses the sleeping soul of man to recognition of the miraculous ways in which Hashem shows His Divine Providence for us every day.—Siach Yitzchak
[He] Who covers the heaven with clouds,
Who prepares rain for the earth;
Who causes grass to grow upon the hills.
Who gives the animal its fodder;
[also] to the young ravens which call.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 15: Not the power of the horse does He desire,
nor the thighs of man does He want.119Hashem does not delight in those who place their trust in the strength of horses or in their own strength.—Tzelosa d’Avraham
Adonoy wants those who fear Him,
those who hope for His kindliness.
Tziyon, extol your God.120The Psalmist addresses the dwellers in Yerushalayim and Tziyon, not the city itself.—Tzelosa d’Avraham
For He has fortified the bars of your gates;
He has blessed your children in your midst.
He established peace at your border;
with prime wheat He satisfies you.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 16: He hurls His ice like crumbs;
He dispatches His word and melts them;
He blows His wind, they flow as water.
He declares His word to Yaakov,

His statutes and His laws to Yisrael.121Yisrael is the receiver and preserver of Hashem’s divine Law, the Torah, which includes chukim, statutes which confine the physical, sensual aspects of man within the bounds of moral purity, and also mishpotim, laws which govern communal life. Among the nations, law is determined by the views they hold at a given time and place concerning the needs of a society, and so their laws are based on expediency.—S.R. Hirsch
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 17: He did not do so to any [other] nation;
and of His laws they were not informed.

In this psalm, Dovid sings of the moment when all the world will be imbued with the knowledge of God’s all-embracing providence. All living creatures—from the infinite heights of heaven above (verses 1-7) down to the depths of the earth below (verses 7-12)—will join together in one great hymn of praise to their Creator, and acknowledge the uniqueness of Yisrael over all other nations.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 18: Praise Him, all the stars of light.
and the waters that are above the skies.122Bereishis 1:6-7 indicates that there are waters above the heavens.
They will praise the Name of Adonoy,
for He commanded it and they were created.
He established them for all time,123The heavenly bodies, unlike humans and earthly things, were created from materials that do not deteriorate.—Kuzari
for as long as the world exists;

He decreed it and it is unalterable.124None of the heavenly bodies transgresses the Divine decree about its functions in the role for which it was created. The sun never violates its mandate to serve by day or the moon by night. According to Ibn Ezra, the verse might also be translated “He issued a decree which will not pass away,” for Hashem’s decree is permanent and immutable.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 19: and all [that dwell in] the depths.
Fire and hail, snow and vapor,
The mountains and all the hills,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 20: elders together with lads.125Elders and youngsters praise Hashem together while the young men must be separated from the maidens. In the Temple separate facilities were erected for the women. So too must there be separate seating in our synagogues.
They will praise the Name of Adonoy,
for His Name alone is exalted;
His majesty is over the earth and the skies.
He will raise the might of His people,
[which is] praise for all His pious ones,
the people near126The fulfillment of the last two verses will take place in the Messianic era. to Him.
This psalm continues the theme of the previous psalm.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 21: Sing a new song to Adonoy,127The old songs will not suffice to express the joy at the wonders in the Messianic future.—Radak
His praise in the assembly of the pious.
Yisrael will rejoice in its Maker;
will exult in their King.128Yisrael is the nation as a whole, the children of Tziyon are the elite of the people.—Seporno
They will praise His Name with dance;
they will make music to Him.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 22: with deliverance.129Although Hashem desires all His people, nevertheless, our ultimate salvation will come through the merit of His humble ones.—Rav Simcha Bunim of Pczyscha
The pious will rejoice in honor;
they will sing joyously upon their beds.
High praises of the Almighty in their throats,

and a double-edged sword in their hand.130One’s praise of Hashem emanating from deep within him (not mere lip service), becomes a two-edged sword, for it protects him against attack from his fellow men and it guards him from adversity in the approaching Divine judgment.—S.R. Hirsch
To perform vengeance upon the nations,
To bind their kings with chains,
and their nobles with iron fetters.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 23: it131The Divine judgment itself is honor and recognition for those who commit their entire lives and efforts to Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch is the splendor of all His pious ones.
This psalm recapitulates all the previous hymns and tells how God is revealed through His mighty deeds.
Praise the Almighty in His Sanctuary132His “Sanctuary” refers to the world of angels who minister to Him as He appears on His throne.—Radak
Praise God in the firmament of His might133The firmament of His might refers to the heavenly spheres through which Hashem reveals His mastery over the physical world.—Radak
Praise Him for His mighty deeds;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 24: according to the abundance of His greatness.
Praise Him with the blowing of the shofar;134The shofar is the solemn instrument which awakens and calls us to Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch
praise Him with lyre and harp.135Lyre and harp are instruments which express man’s meditation upon Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch
Praise Him with drum and dance.136Drum and dance are public manifestations of exultation in Hashem.—S.R. Hirsch
with stringed instruments and flute.137Stringed instruments and the flute may serve to express the quieter rejoicing of an individual.—S.R. Hirsch
Praise Him with resounding cymbals.138The cymbal is an instrument of extremely loud sound which may serve to call whole groups to attentive participation.—S.R. Hirsch
Let every soul praise God. Praise God.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 25: Praise God.139This verse is repeated to mark the end of the Tehillim included in the Pesukei Dezimrah.—Avudraham

The following selected verses from Psalms mark the close of the individual books of Psalms. Eitz Yoseif notes that these verses may constitute a sort of blessing marking the close of the Pesukei Dezimrah.
Amein and Amein!140Tehillim 89:53. Hashem is the eternal source of blessing. We merely declare His blessedness, we do not bless Him.
Who alone performs wonders.142“Alone” means without intermediaries (Malbim); also without the beneficiary’s awareness (Gaon of Vilna).
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 26: And blessed is the Name of His glory forever,
and may His glory fill the whole earth.

Amein and Amein!143Tehillim 72:18-19. This verse will be fulfilled in Messianic times when all men will be invested with a true awareness of Hashem’s majesty. The prophet (Yeshaya 11:9) foretells, “For (then) the earth shall be filled with the knowledge of Adonoy as the waters cover the sea.”—Radak

The custom of reciting the following additions to Pesukei Dezimrah is mentioned as early as the Gaonic era, specifically by Rav Amram Gaon. These verses were incorporated into our daily prayers because they speak so eloquently of God’s majesty, and of the Divine providence which is the source of the power, riches, might, and honor of all human beings.

The first four verses (1 Chronicles 29:10-13) relate Dovid’s blessing to God, when he presented the gold, silver, and jewels he amassed for the construction of the Holy Temple. It was a day of great rejoicing as, following Dovid’s example, the leaders and princes also presented generous gifts for the construction of the Temple.
The following until after ישתבח should be said standing.
in the presence of all the assembly;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 27: God of Yisrael, our Father,144Dovid singles out Yaakov because he was the first Patriarch to mention building a house of Hashem (Bereishis 28:22), “Then shall this stone which I have set for a pillar be Hashem’s house.”—Radak
is the greatness, the might, the glory

the victory and the beauty,145Dovid thus renders unto Hashem the greatness Hashem has given him. His might in war, his victories in battle, and the majesty of his kingdom, are all due to Hashem’s providence.—Iyun T’filah
for all that is in heaven and on earth
[is Yours]; Yours, Adonoy, is the kingdom
The riches and the honor come from You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 28: in Your hand are power and might,
to bestow greatness and strength upon all.
and praise Your glorious Name.146Divrei Hayamim I 29:10-13.
You alone are Adonoy;147This is an affirmation of Hashem’s unity: “Adonoy is One.”
the skies of skies148This denotes the highest of the seven heavens.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 29: and all their hosts,149This signifies the sun, moon, and stars.
the earth and all that is upon it,
the seas and all that is in them;
and You give life to all of them,
and the heavenly hosts150These are the angelic beings that worship Adonoy. bow before You.
and brought him out of Ur Kasdim
and established his name (as) Avraham.151This was not a mere changing of names. Avraham was elevated and attained new stature as a patriarch by virtue of his new name.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 30: faithful before You,152This was demonstrated when he was ready to sacrifice Yitzchak.

and You made the covenant with him153In some congregations, וְכָרות is recited responsively on the day of a circumcision. Consequently, some siddurim indicate that a new paragraph begins here. But it is actually a continuation of the verse.
to give the land of the Canaanites,
the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizites,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 31: And You imposed signs and wonders
against Pharaoh and all his servants
and all the people of his land,
that they acted malevolently against them;154Them = the Jews in Egypt.
and (thus) You have made a name for Yourself,

like this day.155The miracles and wonders of the Shemos have not and will not be forgotten. Each generation reaffirms its testimony to Hashem’s might against the Egyptians and thus the event remains as vivid and real as though it occurred today.
And the sea, You split before them,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 18_Yehi Kevod, 32: and they went through the midst of the sea
like a stone into mighty waters.156Nechemiah 9:6-11
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 19_Shiras Hayam,: In Temple times Shiras Hayam, the Song of the Sea, was sung by the Levites when the daily afternoon sacrifice was offered.157Maseches Rosh Hashana 31a, mentions that the Ode was sung at Minchah on Shabbos. After the destruction, the Jews of the Holy Land continued the tradition, reciting the Shira at the end of the Pesukei Dezimrah. The custom spread to Italy and from there to other Jewish communities. This daily recital is mentioned by Rav Saadya Gaon but not as an obligatory part of the service. Rambam calls it a “custom.”158Hilchos Tefillah 7:13. Subsequently adopted by all communities, reciting the Shira became an integral part of our daily prayers.

Some hold that the Shira should be chanted aloud while standing. It should be sung with joy as at the time of the Exodus. “Sheloh” writes that reciting the Shira atones for sin, so that if one wishes to repent a serious sin, he should recite the Shira every day with great fervor. The Zohar says, “If one recites this song with elation and joy, he will be worthy to sing it in the next world. He will also be worthy to sing it when he greets the Mashiach.”

On that day,159Even though they had been free a week earlier, they were insecure, fearing that the Egyptians would capture and re-enslave them. Only when Hashem had drowned the Egyptians were the Yisraelites free psychologically.—Seporno Adonoy delivered
Yisrael from the hand of Mitzrayim,
the great hand160The use of the word “hand” or any physical attribute with regard to Hashem is merely metaphorical, since Hashem is in no way physical.
and that Moshe was His servant.
Then Moshe and the Children of Yisrael sang
I will sing to Adonoy for He is most high;161When people praise a mortal, they often declare undeserved praise. But Hashem is so great that any praise we offer is insufficient.—Rashi
the horse with its rider, He threw into the sea.
The strength and retribution of God
was the cause of my deliverance;162This translation follows Rashi’s commentary.
this is my Almighty and I will glorify Him,
God of my father and I will exalt Him.
and his elite officers were drowned
they descended into the depths like stone.
Your right hand Adonoy crushes the enemy.

it consumed them like straw.163This verse is also translated, “You will send forth Your fury: it will consume them like straw.” According to the Zohar it thus refers to the time of the Resurrection, when Hashem will destroy all the wicked.
And with the wind from Your nostrils
flowing water stood erect like a wall;
in the heart of the sea.164The water became hard as stone and the Egyptians were hurled against it with great force.—Rashi
I will divide the spoils; I will satisfy myself;

they sank like lead in the mighty waters.165Seporno and others interpret the verse to read: “They, the mighty, sank like lead in the waters,” “mighty,” referring to the Egyptian officers rather than to the waters.
Who is like You among the mighty, Adonoy!

awesome in praise, performing wonders.166Hashem is “awesome in praise” for we fear that all our praise will prove inadequate. In truth, it is impossible to praise Hashem fully, and Dovid therefore said (Tehillim 65:2) “For You, silence is praise.”—Rashi
You stretched out Your right hand,
You guided them with Your might

the inhabitants of Philistia.167The Philistines had killed the Ephraimites thirty years earlier when they left Egypt by force. The Philistines were thus gripped with terror when they heard that Yisrael had escaped from Egypt.—Rashi
Then the chieftains of Edom panicked,

all the inhabitants of Canaan melted away.168Nations on all sides panicked: The Philistines to the west, the Edomites to the south, the Moavites to the east and the Canaanites to the north. The Philistines feared revenge. The Edomites panicked because they feared that Yisrael would now seek revenge for what Esau (Edom) had done to Yaakov. The Moavites, the descendants of Lot, feared they would be punished because of the dispute between Lot and Avraham (Bereishis 13:7). Canaan “melted away” because they realized that Yisrael was destined to take their land, and their astrologers told them that there was no way out.—Rabbainu Bachyah
Terror and dread fall upon them;
at the greatness of Your arm
until Your people cross over, Adonoy,
until [they] cross over,169The two crossings are the respective crossings of the Arnon and the Yardein rivers before entering the Promised Land.—Onkelos
You will bring them and plant them170Moshe here prophesied that he would not be entering the Promised Land, and he therefore prayed that Hashem should bring the Jews into His inheritance.—Rashi
on the mountain of Your inheritance,
[which] Your hands established.171Hashem’s “habitat” on earth, the Holy Temple, is a parallel of the Holy Temple on high.—Rashi
Adonoy will reign forever and ever.

Adonoy will reign forever and ever.172This verse is not repeated in Shemos. But it is repeated in prayer to signify the end of the Ode, just as the last verse of Tehillim 150 is repeated in the prayer whereas it is not repeated in the Tehillim.—Avudraham
forever and to all eternity.173This verse is a paraphrase of the previous verse as found in Targum Onkelos.
When Pharaoh’s horses, with his chariots,
and his horsemen, went into the sea,
walked on dry land in the midst of the sea.174Shemos 14:30-15:19.

and He rules over nations.175Tehillim 22:29. The word “king” signifies one whose leadership is accepted freely by all his subjects. Therefore, in reference to Yisrael who willingly accept the Kingship of Hashem, it says, “For the kingship is Adonoy’s.” A “ruler,” however, is one who forcibly rules people, without their consent. Regarding the nations who do not willingly submit to Adonoy’s Kingship, the Psalmist says, “And He rules over nations.”—Gaon of Vilna
And deliverers will go up to Mount Tziyon
to judge the mount of Esav,
and the kingdom will be Adonoy’s.176Ovadyah 1:21.
Adonoy will be One and His Name One.177Zecharyah 14:9. In the future, Hashem will be recognized by all the nations of the world who will accept Him willingly as their King.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 0_Par: The Mishnah, (Maseches Pesachim 117b) refers to the following prayer as בִּרְכַּת הַשִּׁיר, the blessing of song. Some commentaries suggest that it is so named because it forms a lengthy song that concludes with the blessing of יִשְׁתַּבַּח on page 185. On weekdays, when there is not sufficient time to concentrate adequately on our prayers, we merely recite the concluding blessing of יִשְׁתַּבַּח, but on Sabbath and Festivals we recite the prayer in its entirety.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 2_Par: shall bless Your Name, Adonoy, our God;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 3_Par: and the spirit of all flesh
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 6_Par: From world to world,178See note 55 on תפילה למשה, page 145.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 9_Par: we have no king, redeemer, or deliverer,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 12_Pa: in all times of trouble and distress.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 13_Pa: We have no king, helper, supporter but You.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 14_Pa: God of the first and last [generations],
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 16_Pa: Master of all begotten things,179Etz Yosef assumes that תּוֹלָדוֹת refers to events that occur in time. [See Proverbs 27:1, כִּי לֹא תֵדַע מַה יֻלַּד יוֹם, for you do not know what a day may bring forth.] Thus Hashem is Master of all events. Iyun Tefiloh says that בְּרִיוֹת, created beings, refers to everything Hashem created during the six days of creation, whereas תּוֹלָדוֹת refers to those things that come forth, i.e., were “born” from the original created things. Thus He is Hashem of all created things and Master of all begotten things even though they appear as products of nature.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 17_Pa: Who is extolled with a multitude of praises,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 18_Pa: Who conducts His world with kindliness
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 23_Pa: and He gives speech to the mute,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 25_Pa: He supports those who have fallen
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 27_Pa: To You alone we give thanks.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 28_Pa: Even if our mouths were filled with song
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 29_Pa: like the sea,180Just like the sea is filled with water.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 31_Pa: like the roaring of its waves,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 33_Pa: like the breadth of the firmament,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 35_Pa: like the sun and the moon,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 38_Pa: and our feet light as the deer—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 47_Pa: for our fathers and for us:
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 50_Pa: from the house of bondage, You liberated us;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 52_Pa: and in [times of] plenty, You fed us;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 53_Pa: from the sword You saved us
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 54_Pa: and from pestilence You removed us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 55_Pa: and from severe and lingering sicknesses,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 59_Pa: and Your kindliness has not forsaken us.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 60_Pa: Do not abandon us, Adonoy, our God,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 63_Pa: the limbs which You apportioned for us,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 65_Pa: that You have breathed into our nostrils,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 66_Pa: and the tongue You have set in our mouth—
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 69_Pa: revere, sanctify, and proclaim the sovereignty
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 71_Pa: For every mouth will thank You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 74_Pa: and every knee will bend to You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 82_Pa: Adonoy! who is like unto You?”
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 86_Pa: from one who would rob him.181Tehillim 35:10.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 89_Pa: And who can be compared to You?
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 91_Pa: the Great, the Powerful, the Awesome
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 94_Pa: We will extol You, we will praise You,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 100_P: and all that is within me [bless]
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 103_P: in the power of Your might;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 104_P: Great in the honor of Your Name,
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 106_P: and awesome through Your awesome deeds;
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 20_Nishmas, 107_P: On the second day of Rosh Hashana continue “The King,” on page 475.
text.6_The Morning Prayers, 21_First Day of R: exalted and holy is His Name.
for the upright, praise is fitting.
Through the mouth of the upright,
and with the words of the righteous
and by the tongue of the pious,
and in the midst of the holy,
of Your people, the House of Yisrael;
glorified will be Your Name, our King,
Adonoy, our God and God of our fathers,
to thank, to extol, and to praise;
to glorify, to exalt, and to honor;
to bless, to elevate, and to acclaim [You,]
Rabbeinu Alfasi (Maseches Berachos 32) refers to Baruch She’amar as the opening blessing of the Pesukei Dezimrah, and Yishtabach as the concluding blessing.
Praised be Your Name forever, our King,
Almighty the great and holy King
For to You it is fitting [to offer]
song and praise, glorification and hymns,
of [to Whom we offer our] thanksgiving,
Master of [Whom we praise for His] wonders,
In this Psalm, the Jewish soul sings of the Jewish spirit ascending from the depths of the deepest misery of all, the burden of sin and guilt.
I have called to You, Adonoy.
to the voice of my supplications.
If You God should take account of iniquities,
in order that You be feared.
I hope for Adonoy, my soul hopes;
and for His word, I wait.
for with Adonoy there is loving-kindness,
and with Him there is much redemption.
The Half-Kaddish is recited by the Chazzan
Here, as elsewhere in the Liturgy, the Half-Kaddish marks the end of a distinct section of the prayers, in this case, the Pesukei Dezimrah.
It is called the Half-Kaddish, the final three verses of the complete Kaddish having been omitted.
Exalted and sanctified be His great Name
in the world which He created
and may He rule His Kingdom
in your lifetime and in your days,
of the entire House of Yisrael,
speedily and in the near future—
May His great Name be blessed
be the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He;
which we utter in the world—and say Amein.

It has become a universally accepted custom to recite Barechu before proceeding to the blessings of Shema. Barechu, like Kaddish and Kedushah, cannot be recited unless a quorum—a minyan of ten adult males—is present. Barechu is also said by one who is called upon to read from the Torah.
The practice of saying Barechu is mentioned numerous times in the Talmud. It is even cited in the Mishnah (Maseches Berachos 49b) in the names of Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael.
The congregation responds and the Chazzan repeats:

The two blessings יוֹצֵר אוֹר “Former of light” and אַהֲבָה רַבָּה “[With] unbounded love,” are referred to as the blessings preceding Shema (Maseches Berachos 11a). According to Rambam they were formulated by Ezra and his Court (Laws of Shema 1:7).
our God, King of the Universe,

Former1Forming, יוצֵר, is the act of refining or modifying an original substance, whereas, creating, בּורֵא, refers to creating the original substance from nothing. For example, when one shapes a wooden table, to make it round, he “forms” the wood, the original substance which was “created.” Similarly, Hashem “forms the light” which is His act of modifying or limiting the darkness He created.—Siddur HaGra of light,

Maker2Making, עושֶׂה, is the act of completion, such as when one completes a table by painting it. Similarly, Hashem’s finishing touch of creation is “making peace,” the vessel that holds it all together, as stated in the Mishnah, “Hashem found no vessel to contain blessing other than peace.” לֹא מָצָא הקב"ה כְּלִי מַחְזִיק בְּרָכָה אֶלָא הַשָּׁלום— Siddur HaGra of peace,

and Creator3The verse in Yeshaya (45:7) on which this blessing is based concludes with the words, “and creates evil.” In His original creation Hashem created the potential for evil, which He constantly limits and controls as the Former and Maker.—Siddur HaGra of all things.
When Rosh Hashana occurs on Shabbos, continue on page 191.
[and provides light] for those who dwell on it

with compassion;4Hashem causes light to appear in stages, gradually. This is an act of great compassion for if He made it appear all at once, we would be overwhelmed and blinded by its brightness.— Avudraham
renews every day, continually,5Hashem is not a far-off observer of a mechanism which He created and ignores, but a Living Ruler, Who guides the universe and continually maintains it.
How many are Your works, Adonoy;
You made them all with wisdom,
the earth is full of Your possessions.6Lit., Your acquisitions: See Bereishis 14:22.
The King Who alone is exalted from then,7I.e., before Creation, See p. 9: Hashem was King before all creatures were created.
from the beginning of time.8I.e., after Creation. Ever since Creation, Hashem has been praised and glorified by His creatures.
The blessed Almighty, great in knowledge,
prepared and made the rays of the sun.
for the glory of His Name:9See Yeshaya 43:7: “All that is called by My Name, I have created for My glory.”—Avudraham
